To test if KC contribute to the early increase in biliary GSSG i.e., oxidative stress), KC function was inhibited by pretreat- ent with GdCl3. GdCl3 pretreatment did not inhibit the 1,2- CB-induced formation of GSSG, suggesting that the early ncreases in GSSG are KC independent. Therefore, we hypoth- size that 1,2-DCB induces two oxidative events in vivo. The rst, as investigated in this study, is the oxidative insult oc- urring from bioactivation of the compound by hepatocytes as videnced by increases in GSSG. The second occurs from KC elease of superoxide anion. The results indicate that bioacti- ation-mediated oxidative stress does not lead to overt necro- is, but rather, compromises the ability of hepatocytes to pro- ect themselves from the consequences of KC activation. learly, the hepatocytes of F-344 rats are more compromised han those of SD rats following 1,2-DCB exposure (i.e., earlier oss of GSH, greater intracellular oxidative stress, and en- anced peroxidative damage). It is likely that these compro- ised hepatocytes of the F-344 rat release factors that result in ctivation of KC and a more substantial inflammatory re- ponse. The increase in lipid peroxidation following oxidative tress may also have a function in activating inflammatory cells ince lipid degradation products (i.e., aldehydes) have been hown to be chemoattractants (Di Mauro et al., 1995; Muller et l., 1996). In summary, data from these and previously reported studies emonstrate that 1,2-DCB undergoes P-450-dependent bioac- ivation in both F-344 and SD rats. However, this bioactivation nduces an early oxidative stress that is greater in the F-344 rat han the SD rat. The result of this early oxidative stress appears o upregulate KC activity in F-344 rats. This enhanced KC ctivation plays a key role in the subsequent hepatic damage aused by 1,2-DCB administration. Further studies designed to xamine differences in the bioactivation of 1,2-DCB between -344 and SD rats and the mechanisms of KC activation will elp elucidate the underlying mechanisms of 1,2-DCB-induced iver damage. The established relationship between microbiota and host health has been further detailed by recent studies. The actions of gastrointesti- nalmicrobes have been reported to be associatedwith several biological functions such as energy homeostasis (Nicholson et al., 2012; Kimura et al., 2013), immune responses (Ivanov et al., 2009; Umesaki et al., 1999) and central nervous system functions (Rhee et al., 2009; Cryan and Dinan, 2012;Matsumoto et al., 2013). Although the benefits of bac- terial gut flora are well documented, the effects of metabolites of long chain fatty acids generated by gut microbes have been poorly under- stood. Owing to the efficient production of multiple fatty acid interme- diates through metabolic conversion by L. plantarum, the biological functions of fatty acid metabolites are gradually being uncovered. We propose that fatty acid metabolites generated by gastrointestinal mi- crobes are key players in the relationship between foods,microbacterial flora, and host health. In conclusion, this study demonstrates that TCDD exposure results in an increase in ROS production in endothelial cells that is AhR- dependent and downstream of CYP1A1 induction. As others have shown that CYP1A1 contributes to ROS production in isolated liver microsomes (Puntarulo and Cederbaum, 1998; Shertzer et al., 2004b), our results suggest that this also occurs in human vascular endothelial cells. Finally, this study provides insight into a potential role of CYP1A1 in TCDD-induced hypertension and endothelial dysfunction in vivo. Future studies will use this cell culture model to investigate the underlying mechanism of CYP1A1-dependent ROS production. References Discussion Acknowledgments References

In conclusion, this study suggests that the function and pathology of the intestinal brush border membrane at 10 days after TCDD treatment is in a stage of repair from the damage produced by TCDD. Accumulated evidence shows that highly toxic dioxins reduce glucose availability, reflected by a reduction in the blood glucose level (Christian et al., 1986), suppression of phosphoenolpyruvate carbox- ykinase and glucose-6-phosphatase activities (Weber et al., 1991), depression of insulin secretion (Matsumura, 1995), and suppression of intermediary glucose metabolism (Ishii and Oguri, 2002; Ishii et al., 1997). The increased glucose absorption in the intestine produced by TCDD reported here seems to be a biological feedback response to combat the imbalance in glucose utilization. Further studies are needed to clarify the mechanisms governing the facilitation of intestinal glucose absorption by TCDD. content.CoiStatement: We propose a model via which 27OHChol and 7αOHChol leads to the predominance of Th1 cells in atherosclerotic lesions on the basis of our results and previous findings (Fig. 7). Cholesterol deposited in the artery undergoes oxidative modification to oxysterols. Exposure of monocytic cells to 27OHChol or 7αOHChol results in increased tran- scription and secretion of CCR5 ligands, like CCL3 and CCL4, which leads to a concentration gradient of the chemokines. Among the T lym- phocytes that are attached to cell adhesion molecules expressed on the activated endothelial cells, CCR5-expressing Th1 cells recognize the gra- dient and follow the signal of increasing chemokine concentration to- wards the source of the chemokines, whereas other subtypes of T cells that do not express CCR5 (Tregs and Th2 cells) do not respond, yielding predominance of Th1 cells in the atherosclerotic lesions. Since oxLDL in- duces expression of cell adhesion molecules on endothelial cells, there- by enhancing attachment of monocytes and T lymphocytes to the endothelial cells (Takei et al., 2001), existence of oxLDL will accelerate recruitment of Th1 lymphocytes in response to 27OHChol or 7αOHChol. Th1 cell homeostasis is regulated by dendritic cells (DCs). DCs direct the development of Th1 cells from naive CD4+ T cells with a help of interleukin-12 (IL-12) (Macatonia et al., 1995). Since oxysterols induce differentiation into DCs and expression of IL-12 is enhanced in athero- sclerotic plaques (Son et al., 2013; Uyemura et al., 1996), the possibility of differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells should not be excluded. The Luc and TR assays would be suitable for a primary high-throughput screening of thyroid system-disrupting activ- ity in effluents from sewage treatment plants. The Luc assay can discriminate between the agonist and antagonist activities of samples; however, contaminants must be extracted from the water samples before assaying. Furthermore, the Luc assay can detect thyroid system-disrupting activity that reflects in part the metabolism of the environmental contaminants in living cells and that exerted by environmental contaminants targeting cellular sites other than TR. In contrast, the TR assay is superior to the Luc assay in that it is simple and rapid to perform, and relatively low cost. The volume of sample needed for our three in vitro and one in vivo bioassays differs greatly (∼1 mL in the TR and TR assays, b50 mL in Luc assay and b500 mL in the Tadpole assay). The Tadpole assay would be a powerful in vivo bioassay to confirm the thyroid system-disrupting activity of the contaminants detected by the in vitro assays. In conclusion, a combination of the in vitro and in vivo bioassays will enable reliable screening and risk assessment of the thyroid system-disrupting contaminants with high fidelity. Hence, this study determined the gene expression levels of the cytoskeleton proteins in human neurons subjected to oxidative stress. Even though the tubulin gene expression level was downregulated in neurons treated for 6 h, overall, no significant downregulation of the actin, tubulin, and vimentin genes was observed. Hence, the loss of cytoskeletal proteins in neurons subjected to oxidative stress may not be due to a downregulation of their genes but may be due to a direct effect of free radicals on the cytoskeletal proteins. content.Compliance with ethical standards: Although significant effects of tHGA upon AHR were noted, we do acknowledge the limitations of whole body plethysmography in the assessment of AHR. The use of this technique as a sole indicator of AHR still remains under intense debate and in many instances confir- matory tests that employ invasive techniques to measure dynamic compliance and resistance have been advocated. Nevertheless there have also been arguments as to the validity of invasive methods since they may alter baseline breathing patterns. Further investigations upon the pharmacology of tHGAwill employ both non-invasive and in- vasivemethods to gain amore definitive insight of the effect upon AHR. It is also important to note that the present findings, in which all markers associated with inflammation were reduced following treat- ment, do not explain the exact mechanism of action and our discussion is speculative based on existing literature. It is also possible that lower cysLTs in the tHGA groups are not measures of inhibitor activity, but generalmarkers of inflammation that trackwith the others.We are cur- rently investigating the mechanism of action of tHGA through dissec- tion of major proinflammatory pathways in both cellular and animal models. In conclusion, we have demonstrated that our previous findings regarding tHGA's inhibitory effects upon cysLT synthesis in vitro can be extended and confirmed in a standard acutemodel of murine allergic airway inflammation. Doses of 2 mg/kg and above are effective in alleviating all common parameters of pulmonary dysfunction in the above model and it is possible that these effects are due solely to the inhibition of 5-LO enzyme activity and subsequent synthesis of cysLTs. Further evaluation of tHGA in terms of its effects upon other proinflammatory mediators and their signaling pathways including evaluation of tHGA in both inhalatory and oral dosage forms is envisioned. Current experiments are evaluating effects of tHGA upon tissue remodeling in chronic models that better mimic human asthma.

The concentration of formaldehyde reaching distant sites, in particular the bone marrow, could also be determined by coupling the model presented here to a PBPK model describing the systemic organs. To do this would require parameter values which are currently unavailable in the literature (for example, rates of binding and metabolism for HCHO in each of the relevant organs) and hence predictions could not be made to any suitable degree of accuracy. An important assumption in this work is that the increase in the concentration of HCHO in the arterial blood is negligible due to its removal by metabolism and first order processes during circulation. It is important to point out that the D802G/A/K-mediated pyrethroid resistance is not exclusively correlated with the depolar- izing shift in channel activation or accelerated channel deactivation. Although a depolarizing shift in the voltage dependence of activation by D802K/G/A was observed, the degree of the depolarizing shift by different substitutions is not directly correlated with the level of resistance to deltamethrin (Fig. 3). In theory, accelerated deactivation kinetics by the D802K mutation could counteract the inhibition of deactivation by pyrethroids and render the sodium channel pyre- throid-resistant. However, the D802G mutation slowed the deactiva- tion kinetics, suggesting that there is a deactivation-independent mechanism. We hypothesize that D802 likely interacts with negative charges in IIS4 and modulates the transmembrane movement of IIS4. Disruption of such interactions may lead to altered channel gating which is unfavorable for the action of pyrethroids. Identification of alterations in the interactions between a negative residue in IIS1 and positive residues in IIS4 and their effect on pyrethroid activity should help uncover the gating state(s) that promotes pyrethroid action. content.Acknowledgement: In summary, our result collectively indicate that cryptotanshinone, a natural topo 2a inhibitor, has a potent anti-tumor effect in mice, but does not show adverse effects outside of the nude mouse xenograft tumor system as tested. It remains possible that the observed down- regulation of topo 2a could reflect some cryptotanshinone-induced ap- optotic process. Thus, further studies are needed to elucidate themolec- ular mechanisms underlying the anticancer effects of cryptotanshinone, including the upstream signaling partners of this agent and the poten- tial involvement of topo 2a in the induction of cancer-cell apoptosis. In the future, preclinical and clinical trials of cryptotanshinone will also be needed. content.CoiStatement: In addition to the physical and psychosocial stresses associated with low socioeconomic status, it may be mechanistically relevant to point out that the environment also likely has higher levels ofmetal toxicants, such as lead. Similar to CR, lead (Pb) preferentially skewed naïve T cells toward Th2 cells, and cAMP was implicated in this skewing (Heo et al., 1998). Additionally, like CR, the interference with host defense against LM by Pb did not appear until day 2–3 after infection (Dyatlov and Lawrence, 2002). Thus, psychosocial stress and metal stressor Pb may share common pathways, including oxidative stress and catecholamine. Pb and psychological stress have been shown to generate additive, syn- ergistic or potentiated effects (Cory-Slechta et al., 2008), and β-AR func- tions may be involved. β-AR regulation is suggested to be an important component of the link between psychosocial stresses and health (Euteneuer et al., 2012). content.CoiStatement: Overall, the data from this study indicate that the PLNA is a useful model for assessing the immune stimulating potential of metal particles and metal ions, including Co2+ and Cr3+. Immune stimulation was not observed four days after injection of Cr2O3 particles alone at all doses tested in the PLNA. The provisional LOAEL identified in this study for im- mune stimulation corresponds to experimental Co (254,700 μg/L) and Cr (111,400 μg/L) concentrations, roughly 2000 times higher than Co (113.4 μg/L) and Cr (54 μg/L) concentrations found in the synovial fluid of normal-functioning MoM hip implant patients. Taken together, under these study conditions, the provisional NOAEL and LOAEL identi- fied in this study indicate that normal wear conditions are unlikely to result in immune stimulation in individuals not previously sensitized to metals based on the estimated corresponding Co and Cr concentra- tions in the synovial fluid. content.Compliance with ethical standards: Determination of pharmacokinetic parameters. All animal studies were conducted in compliance with the Animal Welfare Act and other federal statutes and regulations stated in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (NRC Publication, 1996 edition). All procedures with animals received prior approval from WRAIR/NMRC Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. Four groups of Balb/c mice (male, 8 weeks old) received one of the following enzymes: (1) monomeric rHu BChE; (2) monomeric PEG-rHu BChE; (3) tetrameric rHu BChE; and (4) tetrameric PEG-rHu BChE. Each mouse received a single dose of 100 U of enzyme (143 µg of protein) by i. p. injection on day 1 (first injection) and 28 (second injection), respectively. Five μl of blood was drawn from the tail vein at 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 24, 48, 72, 96, 120 and 144 h and then at 7, 14, 21 and 28 days post each enzyme administration for the determination of circulating BChE activity and anti-rHu BChE antibody. The following pharmacokinetic parameters were determined from the time course curve of blood BChE concentration: MRT, maximal concentration (Cmax), time to reach the maximal concentration (Tmax), elimination half-life (T1/2), and area under the plasma concentration-time curve extrapolated to infinity (AUC), using a Windows-based program for non-compart- mental analysis of pharmacokinetic data (Laub and Gallo, 1996). Group means and standard deviations were calculated for all numerical data. Statistical evaluations were performed on pharmacokinetic parameters using a two-tail Student's t test. A value of p≤0.05 was considered significant. Assay for BChE activity. Samples were assayed for BChE activity in the presence of 1 mM butyrylthiocholine and 1 mM 5, 5′-dithiobis 2-nitrobenzoic acid in 50 mM sodium phosphate buffer pH 8.0, at 22 °C. The formation of product was followed by monitoring the increase in absorbance of 5-thio-2-nitrobenzoic acid at 412 nm using a molar extinction coefficient of 13,600 M−1 (Ellman et al., 1961). Activity was reported as U/ml, where 1 U represents 1 µmole of butyrylthiocholine hydrolyzed per min. Mouse blood samples were diluted 20-fold in water, prior to assay for BChE activity.

content.CoiStatement: Although SP-NN did not inhibit the AChE activity (Park et al., 2011), it greatly enhanced the expression of ChATmRNA in neural cells in vitro and increased the ACh concentration in vivo. The SP preparations also suppressed astrocytic activation (i.e., increased GFAP-positive astro- cytes asmarkers of brain injury and inflammation), followingAF64A-in- duced cholinergic neurotoxicity, in parallel with neuroprotective efficacy of SAA in the PDmodels (Kimet al., 2011). Therefore, our results suggest that SP-NN improves cognitive function of the AD model ani- mals by increasing the ACh production, as well as by protecting host cells against cholinotoxin AF64A. In conclusion, the sensitizing capacity of RBITC increased following the topical application in nano- and micro-scale ethosomal formula- tions compared to an Et:W solution, according to results obtained using a modified LLNA. These results in combination with data previously published by Madsen et al. (Madsen et al., 2010a; Madsen et al., 2010b) indicate that there could be an elevated risk of sensitization when potential haptens are present in topical formula- tions containing lipid vesicles. Although, the size of the vesicles seems to be ofminor importance, further studies are needed before anymore generalized conclusion can be drawn. Subsequent, non-invasive visualization of hapten exposed human epidermis by TPM, revealed that the skin penetration of RBITC increased significantly from the ethosomal formulations compared to the Et:W solution. Together, the results suggest that the observed variations in the sensitizing capacity could be, at least partly, a consequence of differences in the local bioavailability of the hapten. Acknowledgments We would like to thank Christina Halldin and the Department of Plastic Surgery at Sahlgrenska University Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden, for kindly providing the skin tissue. content.CoiStatement: In summary, we utilized systems biology tools to map the phospho- proteomic response ofWEHI-231 B cells tomercury and found Lyn to be a key signaling protein. Lyn activity is known to be controlled through phosphorylation of tyrosine residues, particularly Y-508 (Gauld and Cambier, 2004). Our finding that Hg2+ alters the profile of Lyn tyrosine phosphorylation indicates that Lyn may be a pivotal media- tor of mercury immunotoxicity. Future efforts will investigate the utility of Lyn phosphorylation status as a biomarker for mercury exposure. We postulate that mercury exposure during specific win- dows of B cell maturation may affect immunity and self-tolerance by altering the way the BCR pathway processes signal responses. This can contribute to the fate of B cells and may have downstream consequences later in life by impacting upon the incidence of auto- immune disease. In summary, this work presented essential evidence that AKR1B10 catalyzes reduction of daunorubicin and idarubicin to alcoholic metabolites in vitro and inside cells. This study defined the active group in anthracyclines that AKR1B10 works on and estimated the effect of AKR1B10 expression on intracellular metabolism and cell sensitivity of daunorubicin and idarubicin. The data suggests that AKR1B10 overexpressed in breast, liver and lung cancer may lead to tumor resistance to daunorubicin and idarubicin. This study result is informative for the use of these agents in cancer patients. Acknowledgments Thisworkwas supported by theNational Cancer Institute [CA122327]. Appendix A. content.CoiStatement: Rats are much more resistant to APAP hepatotoxicity than mice. This is likely the result of reduced mitochondrial protein binding, which limits mitochondrial dysfunction and prevents the oxidative stress and peroxynitrite formation in rats (Fig. 6). These data support the already well-established role of mitochondria in the mechanism of APAP toxicity. Furthermore, because mitochondrial dysfunction oc- curs in humans and probably leads to the necrosis observed after APAP overdose, rats are not a human-relevant species for studies using the APAP liver injury model. content.Funding: In summary, our study demonstrates that exposure to acrolein induces a variety of stress responses in hepatocytes, of which GSH depletion, oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction and the novel ER stress (in the absence of ER adaptive/protective responses) are crit- ical components. Moreover, our data also suggest that the use of antiox- idants and inhibitors in combination may be attractive therapeutic options for preventing acrolein hepatotoxicity. The findings in this study are relevant in multiple settings, including direct hepatotoxicity via environmental and accidental exposures to acrolein; in the use/ side effects of the anticancer drugs (e.g. cyclophosphamide); during the regulation of proliferation/tumor growth by polyamines, and in the case of various alcoholic and non-alcoholic liver diseases where acrolein generation/accumulation may be elevated. Further detailed studies on the toxic mechanisms of acrolein are necessary to determine the temporal sequence of events; whether one death pathway triggers another or whether they are all coordinately/concurrently activated; the relative contribution of MAPKs; the comparative susceptibility of mitochondria and ER; and the inter-dependence or cross-talk between cell death mechanisms. Funding This research was supported in part by the National Institutes of Health grants K01ES017105 (S.J.B.), P01AA017103 (C.J.M.), P30AA 019360 (C.J.M.), R01AA015970 (C.J.M.), R01AA018016 (C.J.M. and S.B.), R37AA010762 (C.J.M.), RC2AA019385 (C.J.M.), R01AA018869 (C.J.M.), R01DK071765 (C.J.M.), National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, and the Veterans Administration. content.Funding: In conclusion, we have demonstrated for the first time, that HCB in- duces cell invasion and MMP2 and MMP9 expression in MDA-MB-231. c-Src, HER1 pathways and AhR are involved in HCB mechanism of action. In addition, using different animal models (spontaneous and experimental metastasis), our results showed that HCB enhances tumor growth and metastasis in lung. Our findings suggest that HCB may be a risk factor for human breast cancer progression. content.CoiStatement: ATPase activity mask putative endothelial dysfunction in lead- treated rats. Moreover, activation of Kv and BKCa channels seems to contribute more to the control of vascular tone in the aorta from lead-treated rats. Recently, using this experimental model, we showed that lead exposure increased NO bioavailability and reduced vascular tone (Fiorim et al., 2011). Our findings suggest that the acti- vation of K+ channels and Na+/K+ ATPase could reduce vascular tone in the initial stages of lead exposure that counteracts the vasocon- strictor action of free radicals. In fact, lead exposure, at low concentra- tions, could be considered an important cardiovascular risk factor and a serious problem for public health. Conflict of interest statement None declared. Activation of Respiratory Burst in Human Granulocytes by Polychlorinated Biphenyls: A Structure-Activity Study p e 2 F i t s p a V m p u s ( ( m w a v c n p r s s t s b t K 123PCB ACTIVATION OF RESPIRATORY BURST small PCB congeners such as 2,29-DCB and 2,6-DCB (TSA 5 200.8 3 102 20 m2 and 206.46 3 102 20 m2, respectively) were otent elevators of intracellular [Ca21], while congeners such as 2,29,4,6-TeCB and 2,29,4,6,69-TeCB (TSA 5 229.51 3 102 20 and 234.87 3 102 20 m2, respectively) were more mod- rate elevators. The congener 2,29,4,49,5,59-HCB (TSA 5 67.39 3 102 20 m2) had a small effect on [Ca21]i (Voie and onnum, 1998). This structure–activity relationship must be mportant in considering ortho-substituted PCBs and respira- ory burst. It can explain why congeners with a larger total urface area than 230 3 102 20 m2 are less active or inactive (Fig. 5). Another important factor raised in previous studies is the barrier of rotation (Brown et al., 1997; Olivero-Verbel and Ganey, 1998). As revealed in Fig. 6, there is a correlation between activity and barrier of rotation if the congeners of large surface area are excluded. But it should be noted that mono–ortho-substituted congeners, with the exception of PCB 1, such as PCB 60, are active. As already mentioned, previous studies have attempted to correlate bioactivity and isolated parameters such as the HO- MO–LUMO gap (Brown et al., 1997; Olivero-Verbel and Ganey, 1998). This was shown to have some importance in our study (Fig. 7). The studies are complicated by the fact that the respiratory burst activated by PCBs is a result of at least two different intracellular pathways, intracellular [Ca21] and activation of hospholipases D and C and protein kinase C, prior to the ctivation of the NADPH oxidase (Voie and Fonnum, 1998; oie et al., 1998). Thus, the measured response could reflect ultiple interactions of the PCBs and could explain why the redictive power of the model cannot be more accurate. It is also possible that a structure-specific relationship that is ncovered by the physicochemical parameters used in our tudy could be of importance. The congener 2,29,4,6-TeCB 50) is highly bioactive, while the congener 2,29,4,69-TeCB 51), with almost the same physicochemical parameters, is oderately bioactive. The congener 2,29,4,6,69-PeCB (104), ith a 2,4,6-substitution on one ring, is the most bioactive of ll PCBs. This indicates that optimal activity is controlled by a ery specific 2,4,6-substitution on one biphenyl ring that is haracterized by a low dipole moment orthogonal to the phe- yl–phenyl bond of the first phenyl ring. This might be appro- riate for a receptor binding. In conclusion, it is possible to predict the activation of espiratory burst by PCB congeners based on a quantitative tructure–activity modeling. The results indicate that multiple tructural requirements are involved in PCB activity and that he main structural requirements are moderate size, ortho- ubstitution, and high absolute hardness. In addition there may e a specific 2,4,6-substitution on one ring that produces op- imal activity. Our results demonstrate that organochlorine pesticides are agonists for RARh and RARg and induce the expression of P450RAI1, which metabolizes retinoic acid. The action of organochlorine pesticides as weak RAR agonists and inducers of P450RAI1 may have implications in man and wildlife exposed to these compounds throughout their development. This report demonstrates the usefulness of bioengineering assays, with stably transfected cell lines, for assessing chemical interaction with the RAR in vitro. These assays can help discriminate between RAR agonists and antagonists and generate the complete set of dose–response curves necessary for relative potency determination. content.CoiStatement: The present study addressed the mechanism for activation of the Nrf2/ARE pathway through falcarindiol-mediated modifications of Keap1. According to the results of MALDI-Tomokazu OhnumaF-MS analysis, two molecules of falcarindiol were bound to one molecule of Keap1 (Fig. 2B). Although one of the falcarindiol-modified Cys residues in Keap1 is Cys151, the other Cys residue is unknown. However, we found that S-alkylation of reactive Cys151 residues in Keap1 by falcarindiol is essential for activation of the Nrf2/ARE pathway. Because falcarindiol is an electrophilic agent and would modify many Cys- containing proteins as well as Keap1, one of the most interesting questions is whether several biological activities of falcarindiol are determined by S-alkylation of functional Cys residues in target proteins. It would be ideal to find a product that could offer both protection from UV exposure as well as from occupational and environmental chemicals. The risk of UV-induced skin cancer is much greater than other forms of cancer or diseases that may result from chemical exposures. It is therefore very important that continued sunscreen use is encouraged, even at risk of enhanced chemical absorption through the skin. content.CoiStatement: PCBs have been shown to induce the liver to make more of the en- zymes that synthesize lipid, and to cause increases in plasma triglyc- eride and cholesterol and a decrease in high density of lipoproteins (Boll et al., 1998; Lind et al., 2004; Oda et al., 1991), which can cause the basis of the elevation in cardiovascular disease that has been reported in PCB-exposed populations (Flesch-Janys et al., 1995; Gustavsson and Hogstedt, 1997). In this context, the present study has another clinical implication of PCB in cardiac disease in that the frequency of arrhythmias can be increased with the severity of PCB bioaccumulation. Our present ECG data indicated that the PCB 126 can induce SQT, which is an established cardiac channelopathy associated with atrial fibrillation (Gollob et al., 2011) and one of the leading causes of visible sudden cardiac death (Templin et al., 2011). However, the shortening of the QT interval was revealed to be an imperfect surrogate marker of an increased risk for arrhythmic events. Nonetheless, the important aspect of our study is that the en- vironmental toxicants, PCBs are the potent effectors of the acute car- diac electrophysiology including ECG, ventricular action potential, and channel activity, resulting in toxic effects on the cardiac function especially in view of the possibly serious accumulation of the PCBs in human body. content.Acknowledgement: In conclusion, the sarin-mimicking organophosphorus compound BIMP induced a prolonged increase in heart rate and blood pressure when injected intravenously at a relatively high dose in atropinised rats under conditions of anaesthesia and artificial ventilation. It is suggested that BIMP induces overstimulation of sympathetic as well as parasympathetic nerves and thereby modulates both heart rate and blood pressure. An additional mechanism independent of a nicotinic presynaptic effect may be needed to explain the acute heart rate responses induced by BIMP. Acknowledgments We thank Dr R. J. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, the present study characterized the development-, aging-, and sex-differences in the expression of Oatps in rat liver at both the mRNA and protein levels. Oatp expressions are low in new- borns, markedly increase after weaning, reached the peak at maturity and maintained at the high levels for a long-period of time. In rats older than 540 days, Oatps were generally decreased. In addition, there is species difference between rats and mice in gender-specific ex- pression of Oatp1a4. Oatp1a4 expression depicted a bi-phasic expres- sion during the development, which is also different from mice. All of these variations in Oatp expression could impact the drug disposition and efficacy, and could be a basis of drug interactions, especially in chil- dren and elderly people. In summary, this is the first report showing that exposure of males to an environmental chemical or a preconceptional carcinogen can alter DNA methylation at specific sites in sperm, and that the spacer promoter region of the 45S rRNA gene may be a target for such effects. Also, a polymorphic allele of this gene has been discovered, and found to be differentially methylated. content.Compliance with ethical standards: It is hypothesized that the ceiling effect of allosteric modulators of ligand-gated ion channels has important advantages over classic orthosterically acting compounds or open channel blockers, because it offers a much larger safety margin when it comes to drug administra- tion and patient compliance (Hogg et al., 2005). A similar scenario may also be feasible for the hERG K+ channel. For allosteric inhibitors one might argue that when non-cardiovascular drugs (e.g. astemizole) are combined with allosteric inhibitors of the hERG K+ channel, their cardiac side effects might be diminished. On the other hand, when allo- steric enhancers are administered together with antiarrhythmic drugs such as dofetilide whose desired target is the hERG K+ channel, the therapeutic dose might be lowered, thereby possibly preventing ad- verse drug reactions such as TdP. Taken together, the discovery of allo- steric modulators for the hERGK+ channelmight open new avenues for treating clinical conditions related to the hERG K+ channel as well as potentially reducing hERG cardiotoxicity of other non-cardiovascular drugs by combination therapy. In summary, the present study provides evidence for the allosteric effects of dofetilide analogs on the binding of hERG blockers to the hERG K+ channel using both [3H]astemizole and [3H]dofetilide binding assays. LUF6200 emerges as an allosteric inhibitor with micromolar po- tency. Potassium ions allosterically enhance the binding of typical hERG blockers in concentrations that are physiologically relevant. Moreover, LUF6200 and potassium ions act at distinct allosteric sites on the hERG K+ channel, and these binding sites show positive cooperativity. In ad- dition, neither fluvoxamine nor PD118057 exhibit significant allosteric effects on the binding of two radioligands. This new information may be relevant for a further analysis of hERG-related cardiotoxicity and pro- vide novel solutions for proarrhythmic side effects induced by hERG blockers.

content.CoiStatement: Inhaled nano-sized particles in air pollution can be transmigrated across human pulmonary epithelium into the systemic arterial circu- lation (Nemmar et al., 2002). However, there is no data on the actual concentration of ultrafine particles in the blood after inhalation. Although we could not present actual concentration of ultrafine parti- cles in blood after inhalation, our in vivo, in vitro and cellular experi- ments consistently suggest that HSanghoon Park could prevent the proarrhythmic effect of PM mediated by oxidative stress and CaMKII activation. Ultrafine particle is much higher in our study than the physiologic con- dition. Our study cannot explain the relationship between air pollution and arrhythmia in usual condition. However, our study might help to explain the relationship between heavy air pollution and the increased arrhythmia and mortality. Autonomic dysfunction was suggested as one of important mechanisms of PM-induced arrhythmia (Devlin et al., 2003). However, because we used Langendorff-perfused model, the effect of autonomic dysfunction was excluded. In this study, we performed pharmacologic interventions at the tissue level, and the further cellular study will help to better clarify the arrhythmic mecha- nism of PM. content.CoiStatement: In summary, we showed that α5-nAChR is involved in the nicotine-induced increase in cell proliferation and the nicotine- induced expressions of HIF-1α and VEGF via the ERK and Akt signal- ing pathways. These findings provide new insights into the possible molecular mechanisms underlying the nicotine-mediated promo- tion of A549 cell proliferation. Nicotine interacts with a5-nAChR on the surface of A549 cells, activates the ERK and Akt signaling path- ways, upregulates HIF-1α signaling, elevates VEGF, and thereby pro- motes A549 cell proliferation, angiogenesis, and invasion (Fig. 6). Our study provides some clues for the development of anticancer therapy for the treatment of tobacco-associated human diseases, such as nasopharyngeal carcinomas. content.CoiStatement: The morphological delineation of nanoceria uptake and translo- cation coupled with the study of oxidative indices from this time- course study clearly indicate that once ceria ENM gains systemic en- trance to an organ rich in reticuloendothelial cells, it can persist for an extended period causing hepatic toxicity, cell turnover, lingering oxidative stress, and some immunologic responses. The prevalent granuloma formation at 30 days after a single nanoceria exposure and the increased apoptosis suggest the inability to eliminate nano- ceria, which is supported by our unpublished metabolic data, and that the persistent retention of the internalized metal oxides among the surviving cells is undesirable. The reported hepatotoxici- ty in rats that received one intratracheal instillation of nanoceria and the decline in cognitive measurements in rats exposed to diesel ex- haust nanoparticles, lend support to the issue of adverse biological consequences of xenobiotic retention (Nalabotu et al., 2011; Yokota et al., 2011). Hepatic damage induced by nanoceria in this study was indicated by the elevation of AST at 1 h and 20 h after ceria infusion. Decreasing levels of hepatic transaminases, and a well-maintained hepatic cytology offer hope that the observed hep- atotoxicity may be limited. The lack of organelle penetration by ceria ENM may contribute to the relative lack of long-term cytotoxicity and could allow this ENM to function as an intracellular free radical scavenger (Chen et al., 2006; Pierscionek et al., 2010). While indica- tion of similar health effects in the human has not been reported, our study, together with reports on nanoparticle-induced granuloma formation in the lung (Liao et al., 2008; Park et al., 2009), suggests a need for additional investigation of the potential health effects of nanoceria. In light of the increasing industrial, and proposed medi- cal, applications of nanoceria, the observed hepatotoxicity raises safety concerns and invites future discovery of novel solutions for the enhanced metabolic processing of this and other ENMs by hepa- tocytes, Kupffer cells and stellate cells. potency to human exposures Discussion Systematic design of biologically relevant phenotypic cell-based assays Using a biologically relevant model to predict chemical potency Conclusions content.CoiStatement: Finally, evidences suggest that inhibition of the ETC activity enhances cellular susceptibility to apoptotic stimuli (Gogvadze and Zhivotovsky, 2007). Therefore, the antioxidant HQ that produces selective inhibition ofmitochondrial bioenergeticswith G2/M arrest (Fig. 7) could sensibilize cancer cells to the action of cytotoxic agents, which can be considered as a supplemental approach to anticancer therapies, especially in cancer cells arrested in G2/M-phase, which are most affected by radiotherapy (Pawlik and Keyomarsi, 2004). In conclusion, the neonicotinoid insecticides imidacloprid and thiacloprid and the corresponding imines show no antino- ciceptive activity in the present assays. The analgesic activity induced by the nitromethylene neonicotinoid is mediated in a different manner or at a target site other than the a4b2 nico- tinic AChR for (2)-nicotine or (6)-epibatidine. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our data show that andrographolide inhibits adipo- genesis of 3T3-L1 cells in the early stage of differentiation by decreasing PKA-CREB-mediated C/EBPβ expression and attenuating C/EBPβ acqui- sition of DNA binding activity, which suppresses downstream lipogenic factor expression. Moreover, andrographolide interferes with preadipocytes entering into MCE by arresting them at the G0/G1 phase. These findings suggest a mechanism whereby andrographolide may prove to be an effective anti-obesity agent. Conflict of interest The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest. content.CoiStatement: Radiotherapy and chemotherapy are important treatment modal- ities for a variety of human cancers. But radiotherapy and chemother- apy are often unsuccessful, because of acquired radiation and chemotherapeutic resistance of cancer cells (Zhang et al., 2011). These resistances are related to the lower expression of DRs, TNFR and FAS, and resistances are overcome by increased DR expression (Efimova et al., 2009; Maduro et al., 2009; Park et al., 2010c). The combined treatment of TRAIL with irradiation strongly increased ap- optosis in MDA-MB 231, HCT-15, Colo 205, NCI H460, FaDu DD and SCC-4 cells compared to treatment with TRAIL or irradiation alone through increase of DR expression (Kang et al., 2011; Maduro et al., 2009; Marini et al., 2005; Zhang et al., 2011). The combination of TRAIL and chemotherapeutic drug including cisplatin, doxorubicin, and paclitaxel also overcomes resistance to TRAIL or/and chemother- apy in almost all the ovarian cancer cells (Cuello et al., 2001). We found that bee venom and melittin enhanced tumor killing ability of several chemotherapeutic in a number of cancer cells through upre- gulation of DRs (data not shown). These present data provide that bee venom and melittin could be useful candidate compounds to en- hance tumor killing ability of chemotherapeutics through enhance- ment of DR expression. In conclusion, our findings have demonstrated a potential mechanism for the traditional anti-diabetic action of PGF through activation of PPAR-g. GA, a component widely distributed in anti-diabetic and anti-inflammatory herbal medicines, is shown to be mostly responsible for this activity in vitro. By applying the techniques of modern science, we have moved a step closer in unraveling the mystery of the traditional use of PG and the mechanism(s) responsible for its role in the treatment of diabetes. Acknowledgments We thank Drs. Andrew Cheung, Colin Duke, Van Hoan Discussion Acknowledgments References

Fig. 5. Effect of bleomycin (15 mg/kg, i.p. three times/week) and methyl palmitate (MP; 300 mg/kg, i.p. three times/week in alternating days with bleomycin on histopathologic analysis of rat lungs stained with H&E and viewed at magnification 40×. Images were selected according to the alveolitis and fibrosis scores. A: Normal control rat showing clear alveolar spaces. B: Bleomycin administered rat showing collapsed alveolar spaces with wide focal area of fibrosis and emphysematous. C: Bleomycin/MP treated rat showing more obvious alveolar spaces with mild area of focal fibrosis. D:MP treated rats showing normal architecture of alveolar spaces. E: Lung hydroxyproline content expressed as % of control group. a or b: Statistically significant from control or bleomycin group, respectively using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Turkey's test for post hoc. 243E. El-Demerdash / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 254 (2011) 238–244 bind to DNA (Wertz & Dixit, 2010). In the present study, upon LPS stimulation, IκBα protein phosphorylation was significantly increased by more than two fold. Treatment of cells with 0.5 mM MP for 24 hours significantly down regulated IκBα phosphorylation. Thus, MP could be categorized as IkB phosphorylation inhibitors. However, further studies are warranted to explore if MP inhibits IKK1 or IKK2. To explore the efficacy of MP in-vivo, it was examinedwhether MP will be effective in preventing bleomycin-induced lung inflammation and fibrosis. Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic drug used clinically for a variety of human malignancies (Hay et al., 1991). As a side effect of its therapeutic use, bleomycin induces pulmonary inflammation and fibrosis mediated by activation of NF-κB (Baeuerle and Henkel, 1994). Bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis is a widely used animal model resembling human idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (Moeller et al., 2008). In the present study, it was found that bleomycin causes destruction of the lung architecture characterized by focal area of fibrosis with collapse of air alveoli and emphysematous and associated with a significant increase in hydroxyproline levels (a biochemical index of parenchymal collagen content) compared to the control group. These results are consistent with previous studies (Arslan et al., 2002; Punithavathi et al., 2000). Co-treatment of animals with MP significantly reduced the hydroxyproline level in lung tissue and ameliorated the lung fibrosis induced by bleomycin. These results support the potential antifibrotic effect of MP similar to carbon tertrachloride-induced liver fibrosis (Rodríguez-Rivera et al., 2008). It was further assessed the activity of NF-κB by immunohis- tochemical detection of activated subunit p65. In agreement with previous studies, bleomycin induced the NF-κB activity in lungs, suggesting that pulmonary epithelial cells secrete NF-κB p65 (Kalayarasan et al., 2008; Ishii and Takad 2002). Co-treatment of animals with MP significantly reduced the NF-κB activity, a result that is complementary to the in-vitro findings. The in-vitro and in-vivo studies demonstrate that MP has a potential of inhibiting macrophages in general and promising anti- inflammatory and antifibrotic effect that could be through NF-kB inhibition. Further studies are warranted to investigate the clinical usefulness of MP. 244 E. In conclusion, it can be stated that novel N-carboxyethy- lated derivatives of chitosan revealed an antigenotoxic activ- ity toward AO and ofloxacin, and that different mechanisms of protection are involved in elicitation of this effect. While protection against ofloxacin-induced mutagenicity is based on antioxidant properties of CE-chitosans, the genotoxic effect of AO was suppressed probably due to the interaction of CE-chitosan with the cell membrane of E. gracilis, which resulted in hindered access of AO to chloroplasts. We suggest that the results obtained indicate potential application of water-soluble chitosan derivatives, such as CE-chitosans, as antioxidant and antimutagenic agents. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, the present studyprovided evidence that apigenin can potentiate 5-FU cytotoxicity in SEC models in vivo; thus providing new insights for current cancer therapies. This significant potentiating effect of apigenin on the response to 5-FU appears to bemediated through dif- ferent mechanisms involving induction of apoptosis (via caspases 3,9 activation anddown-regulating the expression of the anti-apoptotic fac- tor Mcl-1), autophagy stimulation, modulation of the JNK signaling pathway as well as ROS accumulation; resulting in tumor growth inhi- bition. Therefore, this work constitutes a basis for the putative use of apigenin as a co-adjuvant agent in cancer therapy. However, human clinical trials are necessary to evaluate the potential utility of this flavo- noid in the prevention and treatment of cancer as well as to identify its appropriate application conditions and doses. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, silica nanoparticles induced cytotoxicity and oxi- dative stress in human liver (HepG2) cells in a dose-dependent man- ner. Both the mRNA and protein expressions of cell cycle check point gene p53 and apoptotic genes (bax and caspase-3) were up- regulated while the anti-apototic gene bcl-2 was down-regulated in cells treated with silica nanoparticles. Moreover, co-treatment of ROS scavenger vitamin C significantly attenuated the alteration of apoptotic markers along with the preservation of cell viability caused by silica nanoparticles. This study suggests that the applica- tion of silica nanoparticles should be carefully evaluated as to their potential toxic effect to human health. In summary, both DNA replication and transcription blockage appear to trigger apoptosis following mafosfamide treatment. Replication blockage caused by mafosfamide involves ATM/ ATR that sense stalled replication forks and in turn activate Chk1, Chk2 and p53. p53 seems to be a key node in mafosfamide- induced apoptosis in lymphoblastoid cells, which up-regulates the expression of Fas and PUMA. A less efficient p53 independent pathway resulting in Bcl-2 decline can also be activated in response to mafosfamide. Therefore, it appears that components of both the death receptor and mitochondrial apoptosis pathway became activated. The finding that DNA replication blockage provides a more effective signal for apoptosis than transcription inhibition explains why non-proliferating cells are less vulnerable than proliferating cells during therapy. Furthermore, targeting of Chk1/Chk2 for sensitization of malignant lymphomas to cyclophosphamide (Kawabe, 2004) would rather cause resistance in p53wt cells, while this strategy would have no effect on p53mt lymphomas. An additional advancement in IRIS cancer assessments includes the use of human PBPK models to more fully and accurately account for interindividual variability and parameter uncertainty that can influence susceptibility to cancer. With respect to statistical issues in assessing trends and model fit of cancer data sets, IRIS considers the appropri- ateness of specific statistical tests and the potentialmisinterpretation of a lack of statistical significance or use of inappropriate statistical tests at lowdoses and for rare outcomes. Studieswith a lowpower for detecting statistically significant results should not necessarily be interpreted as definitive analyses showing no effects. Additional statistical procedures used in IRIS assessments include analysis of the combined risk from multiple types of tumors and the application of life-table methods with human data. These examples and summaries reflect the complexity of cancer assessment in IRIS and the challenges faced in assessing the carcinogenic risks from exposure to environmental chemicals. content.CoiStatement: The health implications of mutagenic or carcinogenic chemicals that are directly or indirectly consumed by humans are a significant issue (Clapp et al., 2008). A brief survey has indicated thatmen residing in the north-eastern state of Assam in India chew 4–5 areca nuts per day, each nut weighing about 15 g. Since 7.5 mg/g arecoline is present in areca nuts, the total concentration of arecoline consumed by men (general average body weight ranging from 52 kg to 65 kg) per day amounts to almost 450–560 mg, which is quite relevant to the dose selected for our experiments in the rat model. Arecoline has been shown to be a major cause of transforming oral epithelial cells (Y.Y. Yang et al., 2004) and generating reactive oxygen species (Nair et al., 2004), leading to oral cancer in several patients. Although the exact molecular mechanisms are yet to be unraveled, the findings in this paper reveal that although occasional andmoderate consumptionof arecanutsmaybe temporarily beneficial for male physical or sexual ability, sustained intake seems to be harmful from the point of view of morphological and functional transformationsof theprostate cells, rendering themenlarged andover- active. Such changes brought about by arecoline consumption may eventually lead to physiological discomfort in humans. The long-term significance of testosterone-induced hyper-proliferation of the prostate gland in response to arecoline intake, and in particular, its relationship to the onset and severity of prostatic hyperplasia in humans need to be elucidated further. content.CoiStatement: The consequences of an increase in arginase expression and the resulting decrease in arginine concentration would include down- regulation of NOS2 activity (Berkowitz et al., 2003), which could serve as an “off-switch” for the increases in exhaled NO in the ovalbumin model we observe during the peak inflammatory response at 2 weeks of exposure, and for down-regulating the inflammatory response itself. We hypothesize that an early event in mice exposed to ovalbumin aerosol is an increase in production of NO in the ciliated airway epithelial cells, a known source of NO in the airways (Li et al., 2000). This NO could have an anti-proliferative effect. With continued exposure to ovalbumin, we see a strong eosinophilic inflammatory response, increased arginase content leading to decreased production of NO by NOS2 and increased biosynthesis of amino acids and polyamines required for cellular proliferation, and proliferation of airway mucous cells, leading to airway remodeling. Upon further exposure to ovalbumin, we have seen decreased (but sustained and predominantly lymphocytic) inflammation and decreased arginase content with establishment of a new homeostatic state accompanied by sustained airway remodeling, mucous cell hyperplasia, increased airway hyperreactivity, decreased lung compliance, airway submuco- sal fibrosis, and the progression to “irreversible asthma” (Kenyon et al., 2003b; Kenyon and Last, 2005). There are significant differences in arginase I and II response and exhaled NO in the NOS2−/− mice, suggesting the possibility of an important regulatory role for the interplay between NOS2 and arginase I and II in the airway epithelial cells. Taken together, these results suggest that strains of mice with the most “asthmatic” phenotypes – Balb/c and NOS2−/− mice in our hands – demonstrate alterations in arginine metabolism, and that these strains (and by extension humans with asthma) might benefit from targeted therapies such as L-arginine or arginase inhibition. Our findings also highlight the fact that predictors of response to such interventions must be defined if these approaches are to be taken into clinical studies. content.Compliance with ethical standards: The consequences of an increase in arginase expression and the resulting decrease in arginine concentration would include down- regulation of NOS2 activity (Berkowitz et al., 2003), which could serve as an “off-switch” for the increases in exhaled NO in the ovalbumin model we observe during the peak inflammatory response at 2 weeks of exposure, and for down-regulating the inflammatory response itself. We hypothesize that an early event in mice exposed to ovalbumin aerosol is an increase in production of NO in the ciliated airway epithelial cells, a known source of NO in the airways (Li et al., 2000). This NO could have an anti-proliferative effect. content.Compliance with ethical standards: Decreases in airway compliance were significantly ameliorated in C57BL/6 animals administered nor-NOHA compared to vehicle controls. Airway resistance measurements followed this trend, although the difference was not statistically significant. NOS2 knockout mice exposed to OVA and administered nor- NOHA showed no change in airway hyperreactivity compared to vehicle controls suggesting that the effect of arginase inhibition on the development of airway hyperreactivity is NOS2 dependent. Non- specific inhibitors of the three nitric oxide synthase isoforms cause significant increases in airway tone contributing to airway hyperre- sponsiveness both in vivo and in vitro (Nijkamp et al., 1993). Previous studies by Eynott et al. (2002) have suggested that the NOS2 isoform contributes to the development of airway hyperre- sponsiveness, which seemingly conflicts with our data in which NOS2 is necessary for mitigating airway obstruction with OVA exposure. However, differences in the models studied may account for the differences in conclusions. We also note that airway inflammation and airflow obstruction may depend on the function of several NOS isoforms, including NOS2, as inhibition of the arginase enzymes and subsequent increases in local L-arginine concentration may affect numerous enzymes including the NOS isoforms and the synthesis of creatine, agmatine, polyamines, proline, and glutamate in the lung. content.Compliance with ethical standards: However, the only significant correlation we found between specific inflammatory cells and exhaled NO concentrations was with the lymphocytes. Mice exposed to ovalbumin also had greater de- creases in dynamic lung compliance and increases in total lung resistance after methacholine challenge than the air controls. We observed very faint bands corresponding to barely detectable arginase I expression, but found detectable levels of arginase II, by western blot analysis of whole lungs of normal, unexposedmice. Is this reasonable? We can answer this question by reference to findings by gene array analysis of lungs frommice. Arginase II mRNA is expressed constitutively in the lungs of normal Balb/c mice, while arginase I mRNA is beneath the limits of detection (Zimmermann et al., 2003), which is consistent with our observations by western blot analysis. Based upon the existing literature, which is predominantly based upon gene expression (mRNA) analyses, we initially hypothesized that under conditions of increased NO production (e.g. ovalbumin exposure) we would observe increased amounts of arginase, espe- cially of the isoform I, in the lung. Our results strongly implicate the presence of inflammatory leukocytes, especially eosinophils and lymphocytes, and pulmonary macrophages as major sources, directly or indirectly, of arginase I in the lungs of mice exposed to ovalbumin. We cannot, however, rule out eosinophils and/or macrophages as significant sources of arginase I in these experiments. The apparent statistical correlation between arginase I expression and lymphocytes, but not eosinophils, may reflect the relatively greater variability among individual mice in lymphocyte content at the 2-week time point (Fig. 1), thereby giving the regression model a wider range of values to work with. Arginase I expression in macrophages is known to be regulated by Th2 cytokines such as IL-4 and IL-13 (Pauleau et al., 2004). Thus, it is likely that alveolar macrophages contribute to the observed levels of arginase I in the lungs of mice exposed to ovalbumin in our experiments. These results suggest that the relative contribution of the airway epithelium to producing arginase I in our model is minimal. On the other hand, the large airways would appear to be a significant source of the arginase II we observe in the lungs of mice in our experiments, suggesting a relatively minor role, if any, for inflammatory cells as sources of arginase II in our model. The occurrence of arginase II constitutively in airway epithelial cells is reasonable if we consider another important role for arginase in the cell, catalysis of the synthesis of proline and glutamate, which play an important role in protein biosynthesis. Since we know that there is airway epithelial cell hyperplasia and proliferation in the ovalbumin model, it is reasonable to assume that there is an obligatory need for baseline levels of arginase in the airway epithelium (Li et al., 2001; 2004) and that this role is played by arginase II in the mouse. Arginase I is a cytosolic enzyme, while arginase II is located in the mitochondria (Grody et al., 1987; Li et al., 2001; Levillain et al., 2005). It is thought that arginase I is mainly responsible for detoxification of ammonia as urea via the urea cycle (at least in the liver); it has also been suggested to play a major role in the synthesis of polyamines such as spermidine and putrescine due to its cytosolic location (Li et al., 2001). Arginase II is thought to be mainly involved in synthesis of proline and glutamate via ornithine (Grody et al., 1987; Li et al., 2001). It thus appears to be reasonable that the arginase isoform responsible for biosynthesis of amino acids necessary for protein biosynthesis is expressed constitutively in the lung. We observed a statistically significant correlation between decreased lung compli- ance and increased content of arginase I in isolated airways, consistent with a relationship between increased airway NO production and increased lung compliance. We should note that the overall statistical model used to examine correlations between the various measure- ments that we used in this studywas broken down into subsets of data to examine individual interactions, raising the issue of how best to correct the resulting P values for multiple comparisons. We tested a total of fewer than 15 models in the analysis of this data. Since terms within a model are only analyzed if the model itself is significant, we do not need to correct for every termwithin everymodel. Therefore, to make a Bonferroni correction, we conservatively multiplied model P values by 15. For the lymphocyte x exhaled NOmodel, the P values are underestimated. Examination of Q–Q Plots of the residuals indicated that the residuals had slightly heavier tails than the normal distribution. This would cause us to underestimate the true P value, and, as such, we should not claim that the baseline effect of lym- phocytes is significantly different from zero. It is different from zero for several of the experiments, and the effect is significant overall. To follow the dichotomy of Nassim Taleb in Black Swan (2007), we are in Mediocristan, where distributions are still well behaved, as opposed to Extremistan, where analysis based on normal assumptions breaks down. Surprisingly, the residuals from the lung compliance x arginase I model appear to be normal. The concentration of arginine within the cells of the large airways and within inflammatory leukocytes is an important determinant of the selective role of arginase versus nitric oxide synthase in its metabolism. The intracellular concentration of L-arginine in endothe- lial cells is thought to be 0.1–1 mM (Ogonowski et al., 2000), but this value is probably critically dependent on the arginine content of the medium inwhich these cells are cultured or isolated. Circulating levels of arginine in plasma fromnormal human subjects have been reported as about 94 μM, while the corresponding value in asthmatic subjects was 45 μM (Morris et al., 2004). The corresponding value in rat plasma is 83 μM arginine (Kitiyakara et al., 2001), and in mouse plasma is 90 μM (Mattson, 1998). There is no a priori reason to assume that plasma levels can be equated with intracellular concentrations, as arginine is actively transported into cells against a concentration gra- dient and there is strong evidence that different intracellular com- partments exist with respect to arginine concentration (McDonald et al., 1997). Our direct measurements of arginine concentration in tissue homogenates prepared from isolated, microdissected airways gave apparent values of about 13 μM arginine from mice exposed to saline aerosols and about 6 μM in mice exposed to ovalbumin aerosol for 2 weeks. In preliminary experiments we have performed at other time points, we see a smaller decrease in airway arginine concen- tration after 1 week of ovalbumin exposure, suggesting a progres- sive decrease over time, and a restoration of normal concentrations of airway arginine at 4 weeks of exposure. Thus, the decreases we observe in airway arginine content coincide with the period of maximal eosinophilic inflammation (Kenyon et al., 2003a), and recovery of normal airway arginine concentration occurs during a period of decreased overall inflammation, with a shift to a more lymphocytic identity. However, there are limitations to this experi- mental approach that are worth noting here. Hughes et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 249 (2010) 217–223 linked to a higher relative risk of urinary bladder cancer (Huang et al., 2008).Although the urinary profile of arsenicalsmaynot fully reflect the pattern of arsenicals present in the uroepithelium (Hernandez-Zavala et al., 2008b), these results suggesting that formation of methylated metabolites of inorganic arsenic may be critical to tumorigenesis in the urinary bladder. Administration of dimethylarsinic acid to rats produces urinary bladder tumors in rats (Wei et al., 2002), possibly by the formation of dimethylarsinous acid, a highly reactive species containing trivalent arsenic (Cohen et al., 2002).Urinary bladder has been shown to be a site for short-term accumulation of dimethyl arsenic following exposure to single doses of arsenate, methylarsonous acid, dimethy- larsinic acid, or dimethylarsinous acid (Hughes et al., 2005, 2008; Kenyon et al., 2005, 2008). As found in the present study, repeated oral dosing with arsenate has previously been shown to lead to the accumulation of dimethyl arsenic in the urinary bladder of wild-type mice (Hughes et al., 2003). In As3mt knockout mice, treatment with arsenate resulted in concentrations of inorganic arsenic in urinary bladder that exceeded by at least five-fold the sum of the concentration of all arsenicals in urinary bladder fromwild-typemice. Administration of a diet containing 150 ppm of arsenic as arsenite has been shown to induce systemic toxicity and cytotoxicity and regenerative hyperplasia in the uroepithelium in As3mt knockout mice (Yokohira et al., 2010). Given the high retention of arsenic and the tropism of inorganic arsenic for the urinary bladder in As3mt knockout mice, it is likely that extraordinarily high concentrations of inorganic arsenic would be present in the uroepithelium of these mice. The results of that study coupled with the results of the current study of the kinetics of arsenic distribution and clearance in As3mt knockout mice should provide a template for future studies of the fate and effects of inorganic arsenic and its methylated metabolites. These studies should elucidate the kinetic behavior of arsenicals, provide a model system for the study of the action of specific arsenicals as toxicants and metabolites, and aid in the development of a biologically based dose–response model for this toxic metalloid (Kitchin and Conolly, 2010). •− produced by stimulated PBMC and monocytes (Pineda-Zavaleta et al. (2004). We previously reported that, in children environmentally exposed to As and Pb, O2 •− in activated monocytes was negatively associated with tAsU but positively associated with PbB levels. The disagreement between some results of the previous study and our present data may be due to the fact that the studies are not completely comparable and important differences should be carefully considered. Although both populations included boys and girls in the same age group, the most important and relevant difference between both populations was the exposure levels to As and to Pb; in the Pineda-Zavaleta et al. study (2004), children had lower tAsU exposure levels (tAsU ranged from 16.7 to 465.7 μg/g creatinine) than children in the present study (tAsU mean of 194.6, ranged 12.3 to 1411 μg/g creatinine); in addition, children studied by Pineda-Zavaleta et al. (2004) showed had higher levels of PbB (PbB mean of 20.2 μg/dL; and 65% of the children had PbB N10 μg/dL) compared with exposure to Pb in the present study [PbB mean of 8.44 μg/dL; 25% of children had PbB N10 μg/dL]. Thus, the exposure profile was the opposite, situation that could influence the effects of As on NO•− and O2 •− in activated monocytes. Concerning Pb exposure in the present study, statistical analyses did not show association of PbB with NO•− and O2 •−, and the inclusion of PbB inmultivariatemodels of iAs and its metabolites, with NO•− and O2 •−, showed that PbB was not a confounder or modifier for any of the evaluated parameters. Finally, this is the first study showing a positive association between As exposure and basal levels of NO•− and O2 •− in both PBMC and isolated monocytes, suggesting that As produces oxidative stress in circulating blood cells of children exposed to a broad range of As (from 12.3 to 1411 μg/g creatinine). Interestingly, in this study, only 5% of the children presented arsenic-related skin lesions, but this was not statistically associated to As exposure (data not shown), even though it has been reported that these are the first signs of exposure to As in drinking water, appearing after 5–10 years of exposure (Guha-Mazumder, 2003). In addition, the positive association between As exposure and O2 •− production in stimulated monocytes suggests that these cells, and particularly their O2 •− activation pathways, are relevant targets for As toxicity. The alteration in the stimulated production of O2 •−, involved in physiological conditions in the immune response against pathogens, could be a cofactor, together with other oxidative stress sources associated to As exposure, in the development of As-related pathologies, such as cancer and cardio- vascular diseases. Nevertheless, further studies are needed to evaluate the relevance of these parameters in a larger size sample and the current and long-term effects on the health of exposed children. content.CoiStatement: There are a number of studies linking arsenic with atherogenesis in ECs, VSMCs, or macrophages. Arsenic activates NF-κB, which results in upregulation of tumor necrosis factor α and interleukin 8 productions in ECs (Tsai et al., 2002). Arsenic increases ROS generation, expression of monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 and interleukin 6 in VSMCs (Lee et al., 2005). Padovani et al. (2010) have reported that arsenic decreases liver X receptor (LXR) ligands-induced gene expression of ATP- binding cassette, sub-family A, member 1 (ABCA1) and inhibits reverse cholesterol efflux in macrophages. Our findings that arsenic augments Fig. 5. Involvement of ROS generation in SA-induced LOX-1 expression andDil-oxLkhagvasuren DamdindorjL uptake. (A the antioxidant NAC (10mmol/L) for 1 h and then incubated with SA (1 μmol/L) for 1, 2, 4, 8 h intensity of untreated cells, arbitrarily defined as 100%. An asterisk (⁎⁎) or (⁎) indicates statistic cells treatedwith SA; gray bar, cells treated with SA in the presence of NAC. (B) Effect of NAC on (10mmol/L) for 1 h and then incubated with SA (1 μmol/L) for 2 h in the presence of NAC. Qu asterisk (⁎⁎) indicates a statistically significant difference of p b 0.005 (n = 3), compared to cells were incubated with SA (1 μmol/L) for 12 h, as described in A. Western blot analysis w graph values are calculated as described in Fig. 1B. * pb0.05 versus control (None). (D) Effect of N in A. A total of 1 μg of the protein was subjected to western blot analysis to detect phospho-p6 control. After normalization to the β-actin protein, the bar graph values are calculated as des following SA treatment. END-D cells were treated with NAC (10mmol/L) for 1 h and incubate Dil-oxLkhagvasuren DamdindorjL (1 μg/mL) for 3h in the presence of both NAC and SA. Data are expressed relative to t as 100% (n=3). An asterisk (**) indicates a statistically significant difference (p b 0.005). the uptake of oxidized Lkhagvasuren DamdindorjL through upregulating the expression of LOX-1 in ECs add another molecular mechanism underlying arsenic- induced atherosclerosis. Many studies have reported the involvement of LOX-1 in the molecular pathogenesis of atherosclerosis in both humans and mice (Morawietz, 2010; Nagase et al., 1997; Sankaralingam et al., 2009; Tan et al., 2008). Recently, Karim et al. (2013) have reported that arsenic exposure is associated with the elevation of plasma oxLkhagvasuren DamdindorjL levels with the concomitant reduction of HDL levels. In this study, we performed a series of experiments using a single cell line, END-D. Thus, it will be of particular interest to use human ECs to examinewhether SA upregulates LOX-1 expression and/or enhances the cellular uptake of oxLkhagvasuren DamdindorjL. In conclusion, to our knowledge, this study is the first to demons- trate that SA upregulates LOX-1 expression through ROS-mediated activation of NF-κB, thereby enhancing the cellular uptake of oxLkhagvasuren DamdindorjL. Our novel findings raise the possibility that arsenic exposure can promote the pathogenic actions of oxLkhagvasuren DamdindorjL by evoking an aberrant LOX-1 signaling pathway, thus implicating the pathophysiology of cardiovascular diseases. Further studies, including in vivo experiments, are certainly warranted and may contribute to a better understanding of the molecular basis underlying the increasing risk of atherosclerosis associated with arsenic exposure. Our research center has found that 8-hydroxy-2V-deoxygua- nosine (8-OHdG) in the urine of arsenicosis patients is significantly higher than non-patients living in the same village (data not shown). DNA damage occurs in human lymphocytes cultured with arsenic in vitro for 24 h as measured by single cell gel electrophoresis (SCGE) (Li et al., 2002). The relationship between arsenic exposure in the epidemic areas of arsenicosis and the occurrence of arsenic- related cancers is still uncertain. Defining the exact mecha- nism of carcinogenesis caused by arsenic will require addi- tional research. Moreover, the toxicological basis of individual difference observed in patients of arsenicosis is another undefined issue that could have important public health implications. Acknowledgments We express our sincere thanks to UNICEF China and JICA of Japan for the financial supports which enable us to carry out investigations and studies in the selected areas. Arsenic has been shown to increase the risk of CVD, first through epidemiological studies and now through a labora- tory-controlled mouse model, specifically within the innom- inate artery and at a concentration that is lower than those reported elsewhere (Simeonova et al., 2003). This exacer- bation of a highly complex disease can partially be explained by arsenic’s ability to increase synthesis of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species resulting in oxidative stress and inflammation, hallmarks of atherosclerosis. content.Funding: In summary, results from this study provide evidence that chronic drinking water exposure to As results in hematological alterations that are consistent with anemia in a male cohort of smokers and non- smokers in rural Bangladesh. In addition, we also found that smoking may exacerbate As-induced effects on clinical indicators of anemia. Col- lectively, these findings show thatmen are sensitive to As-induced ane- mia and emphasize the necessity for further research concerning the mechanistic basis for the relationship between chronic As exposure and anemia. content.Funding: In conclusion, millions of people are exposed to arsenic worldwide and these exposures may be associated with high cancer risks. Our results add to a gradually expanding body of evidence that inter- individual differences in arsenic metabolism play an important role in arsenic-related disease, including lung cancer. Our findings also add new evidence that arsenic drinking water concentrations b200 μg/L may be associated with significantly increased cancer risks, especially in people who methylate arsenic poorly. Although the design of this study prevents us from confirming the temporal relationship between %MMA and lung cancer, the biologic plausibility of our results and their consistency with a variety of other research is evidence that our findings represent a true impact of MMA on lung cancer risks. Data such as these are important in identifying susceptible subpopulations who may need specific regulatory protection. Information on the particular toxic species of ingested arsenic may also help elucidate the mechanisms of arsenic-caused disease, which are currently unknown. Funding This work was supported by grants R01 ES014032 and P42 ES04705 from the US National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS). content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, this study links arsenical-induced malignant transformation to the changes that the arsenicals induce in DNA methylation state. The DNA methylation changes in gene promoters emerge and progress over time, are linked to altered expression of the associated gene, and appear concurrently with the acquisition of increasingly malignant properties. Importantly, target promoter DNA methylation, associated gene expression, and the malignant pheno- type were stable in the absence of the arsenical. Taken together, these studies provide early insights into the dynamics of the DNA methylation changes at specific loci that occur during arsenic-driven cancer progression as well as to establish further arsenicals as epimutagens associated with arsenic-mediated carcinogenesis. In summary, our present study revealed that arsenite down-regulated vascular eNOS activity via the ubiquitin– proteasome-mediated degradation of Akt1/eNOS and by direct inhibition of the eNOS activity. We also demonstrated that elevation of eNOS protein by inhibition of ubiquitin– proteasome activity or by stable transfection of eNOS gene could rescue PAECs from cytotoxicity by arsenite. This finding suggested a protective role of eNOS in arsenite exposure. Our studies presented new evidence that eluci- dated the molecular basis for eNOS impairment by arsenite and also provided a potential mechanistic basis for vascular dysfunction by arsenite. content.Acknowledgement: Similar interactions in humans could contribute to the skin as a target site for development of carcinomas. The improved ability of the arsenic-treated cells to survive without attachment to substrate, a property seen in keratinocytes cultured from carcinomas of head and neck tumors but not in normal epidermal cells (Rheinwald and Beckett, 1980), would be expected to increase their metastatic potential, although such a late effect may be unusual in the skin. Further work will be necessary to identify the pathways by which arsenic recruits h1-integrin, h-catenin and other participants to increasing the prolifer- ative potential of keratinocytes. content.CoiStatement: Coactivator recruitment is regulated by epigenetic modification of chromatin, a factor that can affect cell proliferative potential by, for example, Ezh2-mediated prevention of premature AP1-dependent differentiation in keratinocyte stem cells (Ezhkova et al., 2009). Thus, arsenite could influence the stem cell target population for carcino- genesis through epigenetic means. Coactivator recruitment is also regulated by growth factor dependent phosphorylation (Zanger et al., 2001; Chen et al., 2007; Tsai et al., 2008). Phosphorylation and acetylation of AP1 transcription factors have also been demonstrated to affect coactivator binding (Narayanan et al., 2004; Wang et al., 2006). Since arsenite has been shown to impact EGF and insulin/IGF receptor signaling (Patterson and Rice, 2007), exploration of downstream effects on AP1 transcription factor and coactivator phosphorylation merit future investigation. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, we demonstrated that AhR could reduce CSSP- induced ROS production and oxidative DNA damage in lung adenocar- cinoma cells. Although lengthened exposure to high concentrations of CSSP still caused sufficient stress to induce AhR-independent cell cycle arrest via the p53–p21–Rb1 signaling pathway, AhR-overexpressing lung adenocarcinoma cells exhibited higher proliferation and colony formation rates when recovery from exposure. Our results suggest that AhR plays a role in antioxidant defense and cigarette smoke- promoted clonogenicity in lung adenocarcinoma cells under the conditions of this study.
