content.CoiStatement: This study demonstrated the exacerbating effect of ASD on KP- induced pneumonia. The activations of TLR2 and NALP3 inflamma- somes by ASD may be at least partially participating in this phenom- enon. These receptors may play an important role in the secretion of pro-inflammatory mediators for protecting the host from pathogen. Even so, severe lung inflammation enhanced by ASD causes lung inju- ry to the host. The hazardous effects of bioaerosols (biogenic parti- cles) and mineral dust on human respiratory disease are also becoming a public concern. Atmospheric exposure to highly patho- genic bacteria and virus-carrying particulate matters could present a significant threat to human health. The experimental findings in the present study may serve as a warning about the ill effects of airborne sand dust in the world on the human respiratory system. The present data suggest that NO2 could have a genotoxic potential as indicated by the Comet assay screening method, which was covered by a repair mechanism, as indicated by the results of the micronucleus test. However, no threshold level could be identified. Therefore, limit values should be substantiated by more detailed research in the area of exposure duration, at low concentrations of NO2, and possibly testing mixed exposures reflecting interactions with other agents. content.CoiStatement: In the present study, IA and CA concepts were applied to determine the potential interactions among binary mixtures of PMs. Since the interaction differed depending on the titration levels tested, it is impor- tant to test at least three dilutions or concentrations of mycotoxins to estimate the joint toxicity of mixtures mycotoxins if the mode of action is unknown. In the dilution study, we determined that the toxicity of most binary PM mixtures (7 out of 10) followed the additive behavior described by either IA or CA concepts, whereas only one PM mixture (CIT + OTA) showed synergistic interaction by both concepts. This study indicated that different PMmixtures follow different joint toxicity concepts, IA versus CA; therefore, there is a need for testing both IA and CA concepts for the risk assessment of PM mixtures when the mode of action is unknown. The present study may also be used for providing an informative initial screening to determine interactions of not only the ten PMmixtures tested in this study but also other mycotoxin mix- tures prior to animal study to validate the joint toxicity behavior of PM mixtures in other target tissues and cells. content.Compliance with ethical standards: Regardless of their potential interactions indicated by either toxicity concept with MDR in the present titration study, 7 out of 10 PM mix- tures were considered to have no significant interaction since they were in compliance with either of the two concepts tested in this study as shown in Table 1 (Cedergreen et al., 2008). The observed curves for the following mixtures (3 out of 10), including OTA combined with either MPA and PA as well as CIT + PAT, complied with the estimated curves by IA. In contrast, the joint toxicity of the PM mixtures (3 out of 10), including CIT + PA, PAT + MPA and PAT + PA appeared to be better represented by CA, since their observed curves complied well with the estimated curves. The observed curve of OTA + PAT complied with the predicted curve by both IA and CA concepts, even though it ap- pears to be more suited with CA concept. Although the joint toxicity of most PMmixtures were well character- ized with either IA or CA concepts, there were three combinations: CIT + OTA, CIT + MPA and MPA + PA, where their joint toxicity could not be described with either concept. The MDR values for CIT + OTA were calculated to be 1.4 and 1.7 for IA and CA concepts at their IC50s, re- spectively,which did not reach a recommendedMDR limit defining inter- action. However, it can't be ignored that the synergism for CIT+OTAwas observed with both concepts. Therefore, it seems reasonable to conclude that the mixture of CIT + OTA is likely to have a true synergistic interac- tion, at least with respect to BoMacs proliferation.

content.CoiStatement: Although CDDP validation results are quite promising in the present study, the renal capability of the ABST system should be fully qualified using nephrotoxic tool compounds (both positive and negative) from different drug classes in addition to chemotherapeutics (e.g., antimicrobials, analgesics, etc.). Ideally, these selected positive bench- mark compounds have translational effects and are known to cause nephrotoxicity in both human and rat. In this way, the sensitivity, specificity and predictivity of this ABST model could be calculated to demonstrate the usefulness of this new approach in preclinical drug safety assessment (Valentin et al., 2009). In addition to direct eval- uation of candidate drugs on renal hemodynamic function (GFR and ERPF), measuring excretion of a panel of qualified DIKI biomarkers in time-matched urine samples is particularly useful for earlier detection of concurrent minimal renal injury compared with traditional kidney injury markers, or that whichmay occur prior to the appearance of his- tological lesions. Measuring a panel of markers is particular useful since the response of individualmarkers may vary depending not only on the extent and site of injury but also on the mode of action of the specific compound under investigation. Our data support the value of DIKI bio- markers for improved detection of kidney injury and highlights the im- portance of employing a biomarker panel as opposed to traditionally relying on a single indicator. Furthermore, the real time PK profiling in the same animal using ABST provides a unique opportunity for true PK/PD modeling, which may allow for more accurate determinations of efficacy, safety margins and improved predictive capacity in drug discovery. content.CoiStatement: In summary, this study investigated the inhibitory effects of six com- monly used pyrethroids against CES1 and CES2 in human tissue prepa- rations for the first time. The results demonstrated that most of tested pyrethroids showed moderate to weak inhibitory effects against both CES1 and CES2, but deltamethrin displayed strong inhibition against CES1. Further investigation revealed that deltamethrin was a strong re- versible inhibitor against CES1, which could inhibit CES1-mediated BMBT hydrolysis via competitive manner but it acted as a noncompeti- tive inhibitor against DME hydrolysis. Additionally, both experimental results and docking simulations suggested that CES1 had at least two ligand-binding sites, while deltamethrin bind on the same ligand- binding site as BMBT. All these findings will be very helpful for the deep understanding of the interactions between xenobiotics and CES1. Conflict of interest The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion,we have found that exposure to As in drinkingwater is associated with prevalence and incidence of hematuria in this male population with a wide range of exposure. In this first study to explore the association between As and hematuria,we have also shown that de- creasingAs intake among thosewithmild tomoderate exposure is asso- ciated with decreased incidence of subsequent hematuria. It should be noted, however, that risk reductionmight not be as immediate or signif- icant in individuals with longer term, higher-level exposure. Given these findings, it is conceivable that As-related hematuria may repre- sent an early, modifiable sign of adverse effects on the urinary system. Future correlation of As-related hematuria with clinical diagnoses and mortality data are needed to further define this relationship and inform population-level screening and diagnostic guidelines. In conclusion, findings from the present study show the existence of a significant direct associations between organophosphate metab- olite levels in urine and serum TSH and T4 thyroid hormone and suggest an inverse association with total T3, independently of other relevant confounding variables such as PON1 activity and serum p,p′- DEE, which supports the hypothesis that organophosphate pesticides may act as endocrine disruptors in humans. C57BL/6J mice were treated with a modified 4% (vol/vol) ethanol Lieber-DeCarli liquid diet with or without AST (20 mg/kg/day) for two months. Slices of the heart were used for H&E staining to evaluate structural deficits in the myocardium [scale bar = 100 μm] (A). Mean- while, myocardial fibrosis was examined by Masson’s trichrome staining (B, C) and Sirius red staining (D, E) [scale bar = 100 μm]. The expression of fibrosis markers, including COL-1 and TGF-β1, and hypertrophic markers, including ANP and BNP, in hearts were detected by western blot assay (F, G). Real-time qPCR showing mRNA levels of ANP and BNP in heart tissues (H). Serum markers of cell injury indicated by CK-MB (I) and LDH (J). (A–J) Data are reported as the mean ± SEM; n ≥ 7/group; one-way ANOVA followed by multiple comparisons test with Bonferroni correction; *P < 0.05 versus the control (Ctrl) group; #P < 0.05 versus the ethanol group. 4 Discussion Author Contributions Funding Declaration of Competing Interest Appendix A Supplementary data References

content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, this study has provided the first evidence of the MAO inhibitory actions of azure B, and suggest that azure B may be a hitherto under recognized contributor to the pharmacology and toxicology of MB by blocking central and peripheral MAO-A activity. This finding should be considered during the use of MB in humans and animals. Further analysis of the other less prominent metabolite of MB, namely azure A, is required. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our study provides further insight into the molecular mechanism underlying B1-induced apoptosis in MCF-7 cells, by showing a transcriptional decrease in Bcl-2. Furthermore, we highlight the pivotal role of p53 in B1-induced apoptosis and open up possibilities for improving naphthalimide-based DNA intercalators efficiency, such as adapting treatment according to p53 status and Bcl- 2 tumor profile expression. Given the strong relationship between apoptosis and drug effectiveness, reinforcement of p53 activity and/or abrogation of Bcl-2 expression could represent attractive ways to promote naphthalimide-based DNA intercalators-induced apoptosis and enhance cell sensitivity to this kind of treatment. content.CoiStatement: To summarize, our results highlight the changes that occur in the murine uterus and placenta at the level of transcription and translation in cytokines and in ET-1, when exposed to LPS, BQ-123, and LPS + BQ-123. We show that BQ-123 can prevent PTB in the mouse model when administered several hours after LPS administra- tion, by suppressing the pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1β, IL-6, and TNFα, and by increasing expression and production of the anti- inflammatory IL-10 via ET-1 blockade. It is our hope that our results can enhance the scientific community's understanding and appreci- ation of ETA receptor antagonism in LPS induced PTB, and its poten- tial use one day as a form of therapy for women with threatening preterm labor. content.CoiStatement: 147D.R. Doerge / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 254 (2011) 145–147 exposure studies described below were comparable to discrete human populations: serum concentrations in rats fed the control and low dose (5 μg/g) diets are similar to those in human adults consuming a typical Western diet (b0.1 μmol/L); rats fed the 100 μg/g genistein diet are similar to human adults consuming a typical Asian diet (0.1–1.2 μmol/L or soy nutritional supplements (0.5–0.9 μmol/L, Doerge et al., 2000); and rats fed the 500 μg/g genistein diet are similar to infants consuming soy formulas (2–7 μmol/L, Cao et al., 2009). The higher levels of genistein aglycone observed in many endocrine-responsive rat tissues relative to the blood suggest that accumulation is typical and that similar tissue levels could occur in human populations. Placental transfer of genistein in rats was also examined as a possible route of developmental exposure (Doerge et al., 2001). Pregnant Sprague–Dawley rats were administered genistein orally, either by diet or by gavage at doses of approximately 50 mg/kg bw/d. Concentrations of genistein aglycone and conjugates were measured in maternal and offspring serum and brain using HPLC with isotope dilution electrospray tandem mass spectrometry (LC/MS/MS). Al- though fetal or neonatal serum concentrations of total genistein were approximately 20-fold lower than maternal serum concentrations, the biologically active genistein aglycone concentration was only 5-fold lower. Fetal brain contained predominately genistein aglycone at levels similar to those in the maternal brain. These results showed that genistein aglycone crosses the rat placenta and can reach fetal brain from maternal serum genistein levels that are relevant to those observed in humans consuming soy foods and dietary supplements. Another study measured the internal exposures of postnatal day 10 (PND10) rat pups due to lactational transfer of genistein (Doerge et al., 2006). Conjugated and aglycone forms of genistein were measured by using LC/MS/MS in serum (PND10) and milk (PND7) from lactating dams consuming a genistein-fortified soy-free diet that delivered a dose of approximately 50 mg/kg bw/d and in serum from their pups at a time when milk was the only food source (PND10). This study showed that limited lactational transfer of genistein to rat pups occurs and that internal exposures to the active aglycone formof genistein are generally lower than those measured previously in the fetal period. These results suggested that developmental effects attributable to genistein exposure in the previously published chronic and multigeneration studies are more likely to result from fetal exposures because of the higher levels of the active estrogenic aglycone form of genistein in utero, although the possibility of neonatal responses cannot be excluded. A recent study determined the bioavailability of genistein and daidzein in Balb/c mice by comparing plasma pharmacokinetics of aglycone and conjugated forms following administration of identical doses (1.2 mg/kg genistein and 0.55 mg/kg daidzein) by either an intravenous injection or gavage of the aglycones vs. a bolus administration of equimolar doses delivered in a food pellet prepared using commercial SPI as the isoflavone source (Andrade et al., 2010). The bioavailability of genistein and daidzein was equivalent for the gavage and dietary routes of administration despite the use of isoflavone aglycones in the former and SPI-derived glucosides in the latter. While absorption of total isoflavones was nearly quantitative from both oral routes, presystemic and systemic Phase II conjugation greatly attenuated internal exposures to the receptor-active aglycone isoflavones. These results show that SPI, a major form of soy used in the manufacture of food and infant formula, is an efficient isoflavone delivery vehicle capable of providing significant proportions of the total dose into the circulation in the active aglycone form for distribution to receptor-bearing tissues and subsequent pharmaco- logical effects that determine possible health benefits and/or risks. Thesepublished toxicology and exposure assessments of rats treated with dietary genistein demonstrate clearly adverse effects from chronic (e.g., increased incidences of mammary adenoma/carcinoma in females) and developmental exposures (e.g., accelerated reproductive senescence in females and increased incidences ofmammary adenoma/ carcinoma in females). In addition, plasmameasurements in the dietary genistein-treated group rats show that these doses produce circulating levels, and presumably tissue levels, that are similar to identifiable humans groups. Of particular note are babies consuming their entire nutritional input from soy infant formula. The circulating levels in these infants overlap the range of serum concentrations measured in rats consuming the high dose of genistein, for which the aforementioned adverse effects were observed. The very low margin of exposure between doses of genistein that produce demonstrably adverse effects in experimental animal models and those in 20–25% of all formula-fed children in the United States suggests that the possibility of adverse effects should be considered. content.Acknowledgement: 147D.R. Doerge / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 254 (2011) 145–147 exposure studies described below were comparable to discrete human populations: serum concentrations in rats fed the control and low dose (5 μg/g) diets are similar to those in human adults consuming a typical Western diet (b0.1 μmol/L); rats fed the 100 μg/g genistein diet are similar to human adults consuming a typical Asian diet (0.1–1.2 μmol/L or soy nutritional supplements (0.5–0.9 μmol/L, Doerge et al., 2000); and rats fed the 500 μg/g genistein diet are similar to infants consuming soy formulas (2–7 μmol/L, Cao et al., 2009). The higher levels of genistein aglycone observed in many endocrine-responsive rat tissues relative to the blood suggest that accumulation is typical and that similar tissue levels could occur in human populations. Placental transfer of genistein in rats was also examined as a possible route of developmental exposure (Doerge et al., 2001). Pregnant Sprague–Dawley rats were administered genistein orally, either by diet or by gavage at doses of approximately 50 mg/kg bw/d. Concentrations of genistein aglycone and conjugates were measured in maternal and offspring serum and brain using HPLC with isotope dilution electrospray tandem mass spectrometry (LC/MS/MS). Al- though fetal or neonatal serum concentrations of total genistein were approximately 20-fold lower than maternal serum concentrations, the biologically active genistein aglycone concentration was only 5-fold lower. Fetal brain contained predominately genistein aglycone at levels similar to those in the maternal brain. These results showed that genistein aglycone crosses the rat placenta and can reach fetal brain from maternal serum genistein levels that are relevant to those observed in humans consuming soy foods and dietary supplements. Another study measured the internal exposures of postnatal day 10 (PND10) rat pups due to lactational transfer of genistein (Doerge et al., 2006). Conjugated and aglycone forms of genistein were measured by using LC/MS/MS in serum (PND10) and milk (PND7) from lactating dams consuming a genistein-fortified soy-free diet that delivered a dose of approximately 50 mg/kg bw/d and in serum from their pups at a time when milk was the only food source (PND10). This study showed that limited lactational transfer of genistein to rat pups occurs and that internal exposures to the active aglycone formof genistein are generally lower than those measured previously in the fetal period. These results suggested that developmental effects attributable to genistein exposure in the previously published chronic and multigeneration studies are more likely to result from fetal exposures because of the higher levels of the active estrogenic aglycone form of genistein in utero, although the possibility of neonatal responses cannot be excluded. A recent study determined the bioavailability of genistein and daidzein in Balb/c mice by comparing plasma pharmacokinetics of aglycone and conjugated forms following administration of identical doses (1.2 mg/kg genistein and 0.55 mg/kg daidzein) by either an intravenous injection or gavage of the aglycones vs. a bolus administration of equimolar doses delivered in a food pellet prepared using commercial SPI as the isoflavone source (Andrade et al., 2010). The bioavailability of genistein and daidzein was equivalent for the gavage and dietary routes of administration despite the use of isoflavone aglycones in the former and SPI-derived glucosides in the latter. While absorption of total isoflavones was nearly quantitative from both oral routes, presystemic and systemic Phase II conjugation greatly attenuated internal exposures to the receptor-active aglycone isoflavones. These results show that SPI, a major form of soy used in the manufacture of food and infant formula, is an efficient isoflavone delivery vehicle capable of providing significant proportions of the total dose into the circulation in the active aglycone form for distribution to receptor-bearing tissues and subsequent pharmaco- logical effects that determine possible health benefits and/or risks. Thesepublished toxicology and exposure assessments of rats treated with dietary genistein demonstrate clearly adverse effects from chronic (e.g., increased incidences of mammary adenoma/carcinoma in females) and developmental exposures (e.g., accelerated reproductive senescence in females and increased incidences ofmammary adenoma/ carcinoma in females). In addition, plasmameasurements in the dietary genistein-treated group rats show that these doses produce circulating levels, and presumably tissue levels, that are similar to identifiable humans groups. Of particular note are babies consuming their entire nutritional input from soy infant formula. The circulating levels in these infants overlap the range of serum concentrations measured in rats consuming the high dose of genistein, for which the aforementioned adverse effects were observed. The very low margin of exposure between doses of genistein that produce demonstrably adverse effects in experimental animal models and those in 20–25% of all formula-fed children in the United States suggests that the possibility of adverse effects should be considered. Gene–gene and gene–environment interactions are involved in arsenic-induced cancers and cardiovascular diseases through toxicological mechanisms including genomic instability and oxidative stress. Further studies on associations among biomarkers including biologically effective dose, early biological effects, altered structures and functions of target organs, preclinical lesions, as well as acquired and genetic susceptibility will provide better understanding of pathogenesis of arsenic-induced health hazards. Long-term follow-up of a large arsenic-exposed cohort with consecutive collections of biospecimens and health examinations is highly recommended. In summary, our data suggest that in rats, OTB is more extensively metabolized and more rapidly eliminated from plasma than OTA and does not accumulate in a tissue specific manner. Results from this study do not support the role of the chlorine atom as a structural requirement for ochratoxin-mediated toxicity and indicate that the lower toxicity of OTB may at least in part result from differences in toxicokinetics. The involvement of the higher metabolic transformation of HFO- 1234yf in rabbits in the apparently higher potential for developmental toxicity remains unclear. Based on the delineated biotransformation pathways, 2,3,3,3-tetrafluoroepoxypropane 2 is expected to be the only reactive intermediate conceivable as presented in Scheme 1. At higher rates of formation, some of this reactive intermediate may escape detoxication by glutathione conjugation and result in covalent binding thus initiating cytotoxicity. Oxidation of HFO-1234yf may be presumed to be mainly occurring in liver due to the presence of higher activity of CYP 2E1 in this organ. Therefore, liver toxicity should be expected, but wasnot observed. An involvementof the cysteineS-conjugateβ-lyase in toxicity could explain themild kidney effects, However, this pathway is also considered unlikely to be involved in the observed kidney effects, since cysteine S-conjugate 6 cannot be cleaved to a toxic thioketene or thionoacyl fluoride due to the absence of a halogene atom at the carbon next to the sulphur (Dekant et al., 1988; Vamvakas et al., 1989; Anders andDekant, 1998). Probably, an alternative processingofHFO-1234yf in pregnant rabbits yields a stable but toxic metabolite, which is not formed in non-pregnant animals. content.CoiStatement: In summary, although we found some differences in how 3- MeSO2-DDE affects human H295R cells in comparison to murine Y-1 cells, 3-MeSO2-DDE was cytotoxic and affected glucocorticoid production with similar potency in both species. The methylsulfonyl moiety seemed to be of less importance for cytotoxic and hormonal effects in H295R cells than in Y-1 cells, since p,p′-DDE decreased both cell viability and aldosterone secretion in this study. 3-MeSO2-DDE thus remains a viable lead compound in the search for safer and more efficient ACC drugs, although the biphasic nature of the hormonal responses presents a challenge in selecting test concentrations for high-throughput screening of drug candidates. Bisphenol A induced premature births. Pregnant ICR mice were gavaged with bisphenol A in various doses. Premature birth rate was estimated at the cutting of E18.5. Percentages of early delivery are given in the parentheses. 167W. Tan et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 269 (2013) 163–168 A-treatment groups were significantly greater than that of the con- trol. No differences were observed in plasma progesterone concentra- tion (data not shown). Effect of bisphenol A on placental aromatase(cyp19) and crh mRNA expression in mice Since bisphenol A could increase CRH and estrogen in the blood, we looked into crh and cyp19mRNA expression in the placental tissue. Mice treated with 200 mg/kg bisphenol A displayed an elevated crh mRNA expression (Fig. 2). However, this induction was not seen in cyp19 (data not shown). Increased plasma testosterone concentration in bisphenol A-treated mice Since estrogen biosynthesis could be affected by substrate avail- ability, the plasma testosterone concentration was measured. Our re- sult indicated that plasma testosterone concentration was increased by 20 and 200 mg/kg bisphenol A treatment (Fig. 3). The increased testosterone concentration could lead to the escalation in plasma estrogen. Immunoblot on nuclear CREB isolated from the placental tissue As mentioned in the Introduction, crh has CRE in its promoter re- gion. The status of CRE binding protein (CREB) could be a major play- er in the regulation. In fact, CREB protein levels were increased after bisphenol A treatment (Fig. 4A). The optical density data also illus- trated the dose-dependent increase (Fig. 4B). PKC isoforms were differentially activated in the placenta The phosphorylated forms of PKCs were quantified by immunoblot- ting, and protein kinase C ζ/λ and δ were increased (Fig. 5A). Optical density analysis indicated that placental PKC ζ/λ was significantly in- creased in all bisphenol A treatment groups (Fig. 5B) while a significant increase of placental PKC δ was only seen in mice treated with 200 mg bisphenol A/kg (Fig. 5C). Effect of bisphenol A on early delivery Bisphenol A induced premature birth in mice. Chi-Square test re- sult indicated an increased incidence (P b 0.05) of preterm delivery in the pooled bisphenol A treatment groups when compared to the control (0 mg/kg bisphenol A) group. Subsequent analysis by using Chi-Square test for trend illustrated that an increasing trend of preterm delivery was correlated (P b 0.05) with increased bisphenol A dos- ages (Fig. 6). Discussion In thepresent study,wedemonstrated increasedplasmaestrogen and CRH concentrations in mice exposed to high doses of bisphenol A. Fur- thermore, the phosphorylated forms of PKC ζ/λ and δ in placentae were increased after bisphenol A treatment. Because ERE and CRE are found in the promoter region of crh, the increased placental phospho-PKC and plasma estrogen could be the potential activation mechanisms. The promoter of crh contains two half sites of estrogen response el- ements (ERE) and one cAMP response element (CRE) binding regions (Yao and Denver, 2007). The role of estrogen in crh transactivation is obscure. Vamvakopoulos and Chrousos (1993) have demonstrated the stimulatory effect of estrogen on CRH transcription in vitro. However, other investigators failed to show the same. Ni et al. (2004) have over-expressed ER isoforms in placental cells and observed no increase on gene transactivation. Estrogen may even suppress the transactivity of CRH promoter by interfering with CRE binding (Ni et al., 2002). In the present study, the increased concentration of estrogen did not ap- pear to repress the mRNA expression of placental crh. CRE binding is crucial in the transcriptional control of CRH. The phosphorylation of CREB, which could be a downstream response of PKC activation, would bind to the target sequence to initiate CRH transactivation (Cheng and Handwerger, 2005). The distribution of dif- ferent PKC isoforms in placental syncytiotrophoblast has been reported previously (Ruzycky et al., 1996). PKC βI and II, ε and ζ are localized in the microvillus, whereas βII, ε, ζ and α-isoforms can be found on the basal membranes. These PKC isoforms appear to receive or respond to differential signals. Although the importance of PKC in placental func- tioning has not been fully established, many downstream gene expres- sions of PKC have been identified in placental tissue. Yue et al. (2008) have demonstrated that the PKC activator phorbol ester stimulates pla- cental corticotrophin-releasing hormone gene (CRH) transactivation through a CRE binding mechanism. Others have also reported that genes encoded for human gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptor (Cheng et al., 2000) and relaxin (Peters et al., 2000) are also regulated by PKC. In the present study, it appears that activation of the novel and atypical PKCs as mentioned above could be associated with in- creased crh expression. Mice exposed to bisphenol A since prenatal stage display increased incidence of blood-filled ovarian bursae and reduced percentage of cor- pora lutea (Markey et al., 2003). Others have reported that bisphenol A exposure increases aneuploidy in oocytes or meiotic disturbances in mice (Hunt et al., 2003). Aneuploidy of the ovumhas been linked tomis- carriages, and a similar correlation has also been reported in humans (Sugiura-Ogasawara et al., 2005). Bisphenol A exposure during gesta- tion and lactation periods suppresses the activities of macrophages iso- lated from the mother mice and their infants (Pyo et al., 2007). The compound also reduces the number of embryos, uterine weight, and the intervillous spaces of the placenta in pregnant mice. Ultimately, the survival rate of the mouse neonates is decreased (Tachibana et al., 2007). An influence on embryonic development has also been docu- mented (Takai et al., 2000). In pregnant rats,messenger RNA expression of placental prolactin-growth hormone and its stimulating genes Pit-1a/ b are repressed upon bisphenol A exposure (Lee et al., 2005). Placental prolactin and growth hormone are important in fetal metabolism and growth (Freemark, 2010). In the present study, bisphenol A was shown to increase CRH in mice and early delivery ultimately. These studies demonstrate that bisphenol A could be a multi-targeted endo- crine disruptor. 168 W. Tan et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 269 (2013) 163–168 In summary, bisphenol A increased plasma concentrations of CRH, testosterone, and estrogen. It also activated placental PKC isoforms ζ/λ and δ, which could be the signaling pathway for premature birth. The authors would like to thank Professor Howard Glauert of the Univer- sity of Kentucky for editing this manuscript. content.CoiStatement: Overall, this study shows that BPA likely targets Cyp11a1 to inhibit hormone production, though these effects can be reversed once BPA is removed. The presence of BPA in consumer products is a great con- cern due to the numerous studies investigating the potentially adverse effects of BPA exposure. However, a recent study has indicated that BPA exposure in adults can be decreased with certain lifestyle choices. Urinary BPA concentrations were significantly lowered in participants when they ate fresh foods compared towhen they ate canned and pack- aged foods or food from a restaurant (Rudel et al., 2011). Therefore, though further studies should be conducted, our data indicate that it may be possible to decrease exposure to BPA and recover from any adverse hormonal effects, potentially limiting adverse health effects associated with BPA. In conclusion, theBPApostnatal subchronic exposure tomale and fe- male mice induced different types of learning and memory impair- ments. These effects may be associated with the hippocampal and cortical alterations induced by BPA exposure in a sex-dependent man- ner. The treatment with (PhSe)2 reversed the behavioral impairments and molecular alterations caused by exposure to BPA in male and fe- male mice. Therefore, it is important to highlight that (PhSe)2 emerges as a potential candidate to treatment of memory damages caused by BPA exposure, possibly through a restoration in the glutamatergic ho- meostasis but further studies are necessary to better elucidate (PhSe)2 effects. MEHP in the dams can be regarded as a dose surrogate for the MEHP burden in the fetus, DEHP can be expected from toxicokinetic reasons to be several times less effective in the offspring of marmosets than in that of rats. Between adult marmosets and young adult rats, there is at least a 100-fold difference in the sensitivity towards testes toxicity induced by orally administered DEHP (no effects in marmosets dosed by gavage with 2500 mg/kg per day, Kurata et al., 1998, Tomonari et al., 2003; NOEL in rats receiving 3.7 mg/ kg per day via food, Poon et al., 1997). Probably, toxico- kinetics alone cannot account for the observed differences in toxicity, suggesting that toxicodynamic factors (possibly interactions of MEHP with receptor-mediated processes) may also contribute to this pronounced difference between the rodent and the primate species. The results of this study compared to our findings based on the same model of female rat exposure give clear evidence that the bone effect of Cd is gender-dependent and men seem to be the part of the general population more resistant to the bone effect due to an environmental exposure to Cd compared to women. Based on our findings, it can be concluded that low environmental exposure to Cd may be only a subtle risk factor for skeletal damage in men as opposed to women. However, data from the animal model need confirmation from epidemiological studies. content.CoiStatement: 65W. Chen et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 329 (2017) 58–66 after exposure to a red tide bloom (Walsh et al., 2015; Walsh et al., 2007). Rescued loggerhead turtles exhibited an up to two-fold increase in SOD, when compared to healthy captive turtles, which correlated to plasma brevetoxin levels (Walsh et al., 2010). Brevetoxin exposure in coral larvae induced an increase in lipid hydroperoxide content and cat- alase activity in coral larvae (Ross et al., 2010) and induced lipid perox- idation in fish gills (Woo et al., 2006). PbTx-2 induced apoptosis in human Jurkat cells (Walsh et al., 2008). Furthermore, the brevetoxins have been shown using the comet assay, to induce DNA damage in rat liver (Leighfield et al., 2009) human lymphocytes (Sayer et al., 2005) and Jurkat cells (Murrell & Gibson, 2009). A mechanism for brevetoxin induced oxidative stress has not been identified. We propose that the mechanism is the alkylation of Sec 422 of TrxR. The main findings of our study include the discovery that hyperglycemia in diabetes causes phosphoryla- tion of CDK9. CDK9 phosphorylation subsequently leads to alteration of the MAPK signaling axis, resulting in the transcription of inflammatory cyto- kines. These alterations manifest as renal functional deficiency. The data represents the relative im- munoexpression of PCNA (fold change) from two individual experiments. *p < 0.05 significant with respect to PAT only exposed cells. Fig. 6C, IEC-6 cells were cultured and pre-exposed to celecoxib (COX-2 inhibitor), L161 (EP4 antagonist), AH6809 (EP2 antagonist), wortmannin (Akt inhibitor) for 1 h followed by PAT (250 nM) for 6 h and protein expression of COX2, EP2, EP4, β-catenin, c-myc, cyclin D1 were determined. Total cell lysates were prepared and 30 μg of protein was subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by western blot analysis and chemiluminescence detection. Blots were stripped and reprobed with β-Actin to ensure equal loading. Values above each lane represent the relative density in terms of fold change. Fig. 6D, A schematic diagram showing the signal transduction pathways mediating PAT- induced intestinal cell inflammation and proliferation. PAT exposure causes enhanced activation of COX-2 and increased production of PGE2. It activates PI3K/Akt signaling pathway via EP2-EP4 receptor activation. Phosphorylated Akt inhibits GSK-3β that leads to stabilization of β-catenin in cytosol. This stabilized β-catenin translocates to the nucleus and activates TCF-4 and LEF-1 transcription factors which lead to enhanced expression of cyclin D1 and c-Myc.

content.CoiStatement: The use of chemotherapy in cancer treatment began at the early 20th century. Nowadays, despite that the therapeutic approaches of targeted therapy continue to evolve and have made great progresses in clinical practice, chemotherapy is still an indispensable strategy for cancer ther- apy (DeVita and Chu, 2008). However, patients administered for long periods of time with chemotherapeutic agents always display different toxicity profiles, and little is known about the most frequent and treat- able side effects, such as delayed diarrhea ((Wadler et al., 1998; Pro et al., 2001). If this symptom failed to be recognized and adequately treated, it will be life-threatening. For these reasons, early assessment and prevention of chemotherapy-induced colitis are essential to im- prove life qualities and ongoing treatment administration (Saltz et al., 2000; Lenfers et al., 1999). According to recent researches, many anti- cancer chemotherapeutic agents display the capacity to modulate im- mune responses, including inducing immunogenic cell activation or death, to cause cytotoxic events (Lake and Robinson, 2005; Nakasone et al., 2012; Zhu et al., 2007). CPT-11, having great efficacy on anticancer therapy and being used as the first line treatment for colorectal cancer, showed severe side ef- fects, especially colitis (Rothenberg et al., 1996). A previous clinical study has discovered that CPT-11 could induce mucosal injury due to dysfunction of leukocytes (Shinohara et al., 1998). However, the mech- anism of CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea is not quite understood. In our study, we found that CPT-11 induced experimental colitis, including loss of basal body weight, diarrhea and reduced colon length by modu- lating the immune system. We first identified the sensitized effect of CPT-11 on macrophages and the possible mechanisms may due to NLRP3 inflammasome activation. IL-1β, mainly produced by activated macrophages, is an essential proinflammatory cytokine for the early phase of the colonic inflamma- tion cascade and tightly correlated with the severity of colon damage (Mahida et al., 1989). It is now well established that bioactive IL-1β is produced by NLRP3 inflammasome-activated caspase-1 from an inac- tive 31-kDa precursor to an activated 17-kDa precursor. Researchers have already proved that DSS-induced experimental colitis is due to NLRP3/caspase-1-mediated maturation of IL-1β (Coccia et al., 2012). IL-18, produced along with IL-1β, was also converted by activated caspase-1 to their functional cytokine and contributed to intestinal in- flammation. Blocking IL-18 was effective for preventing the progress of experimental models of colitis (Zaki et al., 2010), and it is also con- firmed that some compounds can prevent the colitis by hampering NLRP3 inflammasome activation (Siegmund, 2010). Our in vivo and vitro experiments here showed that CPT-11 significantly elevated the expression of IL-1β/IL-18 and activated caspase-1. We discovered that CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea at least partially due to its activation of NLRP3 inflammasome. Increased proinflammatory cytokine production is a hallmark of in- flammatory disease (Bauer et al., 2010). In this study, CPT-11 successful- ly induced colitis by elevating the levels of IL-1β, IL-18, TNF-α, IL-6 and IL-17A in colons. Moreover, we showed that CPT-11 triggered the acti- vation of macrophages by activating NF-κB, STAT1 and MAPK signaling pathways. It is well established that the activation of NLRP3 inflammasome is a two-hit model requiring both TLR (Toll like recep- tor) and inflammasome assembly (Feng et al., 2014). Transcriptions of proIL-1β and proIL-18 depend on TLR triggering. NF-κB andMAPK fam- ilies were the most common downstream signaling molecules of TLR. NF-κB and JNKwere themost important downstream transcription fac- tors responsible for proIL-1β and proIL-18 transcriptions.While another hit is needed for the release of IL-1β and IL-18, the inflammasome as- sembly is K+ efflux-dependent, lysosomal-dependent and reactive oxy- gen species (ROS)-dependent (Schroder and Tschopp, 2010). Indeed, CPT-11 has an important role in the two-step activation. THP-1 cells treated with CPT-11 showed significantly activation of NF-κB and JNK at a dose of 10 μM. Additionally, the mRNA levels of IL-1β and IL-18 were also elevated by CPT-11 at 5 μM and 10 μM. ROS levels were ele- vated by LPS plus CPT-11 treatment which was comparable to LPS/ ATP treatment. Blocking NF-κB and JNK activation by their specific in- hibitors significantly inhibited IL-1β and IL-18 secretion. Recent re- searches reported that the MAPK family has dual roles in NLRP3 inflammasome activation: P38, JNK and ERK activationwas all responsi- ble for proIL-1β and proIL-18 transcriptions. While P38 activation has little effect on the second signal of NLRP3 inflammasome activation, JNK activation could trigger mitochondrial ROS production and ERK ac- tivation could affect protease stability to trigger inflammasome assem- bly. According to our findings, CPT-11 could specifically activated JNK and has little effect on P38 and ERK activation. Combined with ROS 141Q. Li et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 289 (2015) 133–141 levels, these data represented that CPT-11 could activate NLRP3 inflammasome through both hits. In conclusion, our work discovered a novel mechanism for CPT-11 induced colitis by activating NLRP3 inflammasome. These results indi- cate that inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome might be an attractive strategy in clinical treatment with CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea, and these drugs which have potentials in inhibiting NF-κB and JNK phosphorylation can be used in this condition. In conclusion, our work provides a new insight into CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea. Conflict of interest The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest concerning this article. However, the mech- anism of CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea is not quite understood. In our study, we found that CPT-11 induced experimental colitis, including loss of basal body weight, diarrhea and reduced colon length by modu- lating the immune system. We first identified the sensitized effect of CPT-11 on macrophages and the possible mechanisms may due to NLRP3 inflammasome activation. IL-1β, mainly produced by activated macrophages, is an essential proinflammatory cytokine for the early phase of the colonic inflamma- tion cascade and tightly correlated with the severity of colon damage (Mahida et al., 1989). It is now well established that bioactive IL-1β is produced by NLRP3 inflammasome-activated caspase-1 from an inac- tive 31-kDa precursor to an activated 17-kDa precursor. Researchers have already proved that DSS-induced experimental colitis is due to NLRP3/caspase-1-mediated maturation of IL-1β (Coccia et al., 2012). IL-18, produced along with IL-1β, was also converted by activated caspase-1 to their functional cytokine and contributed to intestinal in- flammation. Blocking IL-18 was effective for preventing the progress of experimental models of colitis (Zaki et al., 2010), and it is also con- firmed that some compounds can prevent the colitis by hampering NLRP3 inflammasome activation (Siegmund, 2010). Our in vivo and vitro experiments here showed that CPT-11 significantly elevated the expression of IL-1β/IL-18 and activated caspase-1. We discovered that CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea at least partially due to its activation of NLRP3 inflammasome. Increased proinflammatory cytokine production is a hallmark of in- flammatory disease (Bauer et al., 2010). In this study, CPT-11 successful- ly induced colitis by elevating the levels of IL-1β, IL-18, TNF-α, IL-6 and IL-17A in colons. Moreover, we showed that CPT-11 triggered the acti- vation of macrophages by activating NF-κB, STAT1 and MAPK signaling pathways. It is well established that the activation of NLRP3 inflammasome is a two-hit model requiring both TLR (Toll like recep- tor) and inflammasome assembly (Feng et al., 2014). Transcriptions of proIL-1β and proIL-18 depend on TLR triggering. NF-κB andMAPK fam- ilies were the most common downstream signaling molecules of TLR. NF-κB and JNKwere themost important downstream transcription fac- tors responsible for proIL-1β and proIL-18 transcriptions.While another hit is needed for the release of IL-1β and IL-18, the inflammasome as- sembly is K+ efflux-dependent, lysosomal-dependent and reactive oxy- gen species (ROS)-dependent (Schroder and Tschopp, 2010). Indeed, CPT-11 has an important role in the two-step activation. THP-1 cells treated with CPT-11 showed significantly activation of NF-κB and JNK at a dose of 10 μM. Additionally, the mRNA levels of IL-1β and IL-18 were also elevated by CPT-11 at 5 μM and 10 μM. ROS levels were ele- vated by LPS plus CPT-11 treatment which was comparable to LPS/ ATP treatment. Blocking NF-κB and JNK activation by their specific in- hibitors significantly inhibited IL-1β and IL-18 secretion. Recent re- searches reported that the MAPK family has dual roles in NLRP3 inflammasome activation: P38, JNK and ERK activationwas all responsi- ble for proIL-1β and proIL-18 transcriptions. While P38 activation has little effect on the second signal of NLRP3 inflammasome activation, JNK activation could trigger mitochondrial ROS production and ERK ac- tivation could affect protease stability to trigger inflammasome assem- bly. According to our findings, CPT-11 could specifically activated JNK and has little effect on P38 and ERK activation. Combined with ROS 141Q. Li et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 289 (2015) 133–141 levels, these data represented that CPT-11 could activate NLRP3 inflammasome through both hits. In conclusion, our work discovered a novel mechanism for CPT-11 induced colitis by activating NLRP3 inflammasome. These results indi- cate that inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome might be an attractive strategy in clinical treatment with CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea, and these drugs which have potentials in inhibiting NF-κB and JNK phosphorylation can be used in this condition. In conclusion, our work provides a new insight into CPT-11 induced delayed diarrhea. Conflict of interest The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest concerning this article. content.CoiStatement: In summary, this is the first study to investigate the role of Cyp2e1 in INH-induced hepatotoxicity by use of metabolomics. This targeted metabolomic analysis identified a novel correlation between an INH metabolite and INH-induced toxicity, and provides an opportunity to establish a biomarker that can be used to monitor INH induced toxicity activity through noninvasive measurements. Accordingly, metabolomics, can be used as a tool for measuring small-molecule metabolite profiles and fluxes in biological matrices, and thus monitor endogenous and exogenous variation of drug metabolism in animal models and in humans. It is worth noting that the villi provide a large area where the CYP enzymes in the enterocytes can interact with the absorbed xenobiotics (Wacher et al., 2001). For CYP3A substrates, the barrier activity of the small intestine may be facilitated by the multidrug efflux pump p-glycoprotein, which is expressed in the intestine and functions in concert with CYP3A (Lindell et al., 2003; Wacher et al., 1998). Our results suggest that xenobiotics that are substrates for CYP3A may have poor bioavailability in horse. However, the role of the intestinal mucosa as a site of first-pass metabolism by CYP3A-enzymes has not been examined in horse. Thus, further studies are needed to explore the metabolic and pharmacokinetic consequences of CYP3A in the horse intestines. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, dauricine induced GSH depletion and apoptosis in lungs of CD-1 mice and in cultured human lung cells. L-Buthionine sulfoximine-induced GSH depletion potentiated cytotoxicity and apoptosis induced by dauricine, while CYP3A inhibitor ketoconazole reversed dauricine-induced GSH depletion and apoptosis. It is most likely that quinone methide intermediate 2 was responsible for dauricine-induced cellular GSH depletion. The depletion of GSH may trigger and/or intensify the cytotoxicity and apoptosis of dauricine. Conflict of interest statement The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest. In summary, the present study shows that oncogene and tumor suppressor gene expression in a human prostate epithe- lial cell line can be altered by cadmium. These alterations are associated with induction of apoptosis. These findings are significant because this is the first study to examine the mo- lecular events associated with cadmium exposure in a cell line analogous to a suspected in vivo target cell of cadmium carci- nogenesis in humans and rodents. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, concurrent treatment with CAPE exhibited promising effects in the protection against DEX-induced osteoporosis through op- posing osteoclastogenesis and protection of osteoblasts (Fig. 7). In summary, the present study demonstrated that CBD exposure resulted in a marked enhancement of apoptosis in nontransformed lymphocytes, which was closely associated with a ROS-dependent activation of caspase-8. The pro- apoptotic property in primary lymphocytes by both centrally active and inactive cannabinoids could be a critical mechanism responsible for the immunosuppressive effects induced by plant-derived cannabinoids. The precise mechanism by which CBD causes oxidative stress and the associated caspase- 8 activation in primary lymphocytes is currently under investigation. Uninjected embryos and embryos injectedwith the indicatedmorpholinos were exposed to BkF at 4–40 μM to 48 hpf, and then pericardial edemawas quantified as increased pericardial area in lateral images. Data represent a single experiment with 14 or 15 embryos per treatment group (mean ± s.e.m.). Asterisks indicate treatment groups significantly different from uninjected controls as described in the text (ANOVA with Tukey–Kramer HSD (α = 0.05). 248 J.P. Incardona et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 257 (2011) 242–249 myocardial AHR activation (indicated by CYP1A induction), which is sim- ply blocked by AHR2 knockdown, restoring normal cardiacmorphogene- sis (Incardona et al., 2006; Scott et al., 2011). By contrast, it is difficult to reconcile the pattern of CYP1A induction resulting fromBkF exposure, the effects of AHR2 knockdown on that pattern, and the impacts of BkF expo- sure on heart function. Consistent with predictions based on AHR agonist activity in cell lines (Barron et al., 2004), BkF is a strong inducer in zebra- fish, causing qualitativelymuch higher levels of AHR2-dependent epider- mal CYP1A immunofluorescence than BaP. If BkF acts directly on the myocardium to reduce heart rate and cause atrial dilation, it does sowith- out evidence of AHR activation in target cardiac cells. It is possible that BkF acts on myocardial cells through one of the other zebrafish AHR orthologs (AHR1A and AHR1B), independent of CYP1A induction. This is highly unlikely, as cyp1a is consistently the most highly induced gene following AHR activation (Alexeyenko et al., 2010; Carney et al., 2006). There is no simple mechanism to explain how BkF could induce CYP1A in an AHR2-dependent manner in epidermal cells, but fail to induce CYP1A in myocardial cells. An alternative explanation is that cardiac toxicity in BkF-exposed embryos is a result of a metabolite of BkF, or another metabolic alter- ation resulting from BkF exposure. BkF toxicity was moderately increased by CYP1A knockdown, which could indicate either that the parent compound causes toxicity, or that more parent compound is accessible to another metabolic pathway. The interaction between BkF and the standard control morpholino is unusual and also could impli- cate a metabolic mechanism. The standard control morpholino targets a splice site in the human ß-globin gene, has no antisense activity in zebrafish cells, and was selected for its absence of off-target biological activity or toxicity (Lacerra et al., 2000) (http://www.gene-tools.com/ node/23#standardcontrols). Some morpholinos have been shown to produce off-target toxicity causing apoptotic cell death through the p53 pathway (Robu et al., 2007). We have used the standard control morpholino with several other PAHs, and have not observed a similarly increased sensitivity to PAH toxicity (Incardona et al., 2006). There are no similar published findings that may suggest a plausible hypothesis underlying this effect. A BLAST search against the current zebrafish genome database with this sequence reveals only two anonymous sequences that have a partial (19 base pair) overlapwith themorpholino target sequence. Therefore, the control morpholino cannot be targeting a known member of the AHR or cytochrome P450 family. The observed synergism cannot be due to a generalmetabolic property ofmorpholinos, because the effectwas sequence-specific, i.e. did not occurwith either the ahr2-specific negative control morpholino, or the ahr2 antisense morpholino. The PAH compositions derived from non-point sources such as stormwater runoff are complex and typically reflect a mixture of com- bustive and petrogenic sources (Hwang and Foster, 2006; Stein et al., 2006). Comparison of dissolved-phase and particulate-associated PAHs usually shows a predominance of 2- and 3-ring compounds in the dis- solved phase, with a predominance of 4-, 5-, and 6-ring compounds in the particulate fraction. While the bulk of larger particle-associated PAHs may not be bioavailable to organisms such as fish embryos that are primarily impacted bydissolved PAHs (Carls et al., 2008), a key ques- tion is how lower concentrations of compounds such as BaP and BkF might modify the toxicity of a mixture that is otherwise predominantly petrogenic. Because CYP1A induction is primarily protective against pet- rogenic PAH toxicity (Hicken et al., 2011; Incardona et al., 2005), the presence of low concentrations of potent CYP1A inducers could poten- tially reduce the effects of 3-ring compounds in amixture. Alternatively, if CYP1A metabolic capacity was already overwhelmed by higher con- centrations of low molecular weight PAHs (which occurs at about 10 μg/L in zebrafish; (Hicken et al., 2011), the high molecular weight compounds may produce additive or greater-than-additive (i.e., syner- gistic) impacts on cardiac function and morphogenesis. The finding that the various mixtures of BeP, BaP, and BkF did not produce interme- diate levels of toxicity suggests that there may be more complicated in- teractions between these compounds, which should be examined in more detailed studies. In conclusion, these findings refine and extend our understanding of how individual PAHs cause developmental toxicity via a diversity of tox- icokinetic and toxicodynamic processes. This understanding is critical for assessing the combinatorial toxicity of PAHmixtures in aquatic hab- itats, both within and between petrogenic and pyrogenic sources. There are numerous implications for improving environmental assessment in PAH-contaminated environments. This includes, for example, future as- sessments of oil spill impacts (primarily petrogenic PAH mixtures) in riverine, estuarine, or coastal marine habitats where inputs from urban stormwater runoff (primarily pyrogenic mixtures) are common. A long-term goal of this work is to develop mechanism-based markers of the biological effects of complex PAHmixtures in sensitive early life his- tory stages of fish. This goal is dependent on a detailed understanding of the various pathways through which PAH toxicity converges on the de- veloping fish heart. Although the results of our zebrafish screening approach with high concentrations of single compounds may not be environmentally relevant, they shed light on pathways (e.g. AHR- dependent and novel AHR-independent) for which gene expression markers can be developed and tested with real-world mixtures. These types of mechanistic analyses using the zebrafish model will ultimately inform the development of a new generation of biomarkers that will be diagnostic of different types of PAH exposures in fish spawning habitats and, at the same time, phenotypically anchored to cardiac performance, heart and vascular development, and fish survival. Cardiac toxicity of 5-ring polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons is differentially dependent on the aryl hydrocarbon receptor 2 isoform during zebrafish development Introduction Materials and methods Outline placeholder Chemicals Zebrafish exposures Morpholino injections Imaging of live embryos/larvae and measurements of cardiac function Immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy Statistical analysis Results Benzo[a]pyrene and benzo[k]fluoranthene exposure results in distinct cardiac defects Benzo[a]pyrene, benzo[e]pyrene, and benzo[k]fluoranthene induce CYP1A in distinct tissue-specific patterns Cardiac toxicity of benzo[a]pyrene but not benzo[k]fluoranthene is AHR2-dependent Discussion Conflict of interest statement Acknowledgments References
content.Acknowledgement: Fig. 6. BkF cardiotoxicity is AHR2- and CYP1A-independent across a range of doses. Uninjected embryos and embryos injectedwith the indicatedmorpholinos were exposed to BkF at 4–40 μM to 48 hpf, and then pericardial edemawas quantified as increased pericardial area in lateral images. Data represent a single experiment with 14 or 15 embryos per treatment group (mean ± s.e.m.). Asterisks indicate treatment groups significantly different from uninjected controls as described in the text (ANOVA with Tukey–Kramer HSD (α = 0.05). 248 J.P. Incardona et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 257 (2011) 242–249 myocardial AHR activation (indicated by CYP1A induction), which is sim- ply blocked by AHR2 knockdown, restoring normal cardiacmorphogene- sis (Incardona et al., 2006; Scott et al., 2011). By contrast, it is difficult to reconcile the pattern of CYP1A induction resulting fromBkF exposure, the effects of AHR2 knockdown on that pattern, and the impacts of BkF expo- sure on heart function. Consistent with predictions based on AHR agonist activity in cell lines (Barron et al., 2004), BkF is a strong inducer in zebra- fish, causing qualitativelymuch higher levels of AHR2-dependent epider- mal CYP1A immunofluorescence than BaP. If BkF acts directly on the myocardium to reduce heart rate and cause atrial dilation, it does sowith- out evidence of AHR activation in target cardiac cells. It is possible that BkF acts on myocardial cells through one of the other zebrafish AHR orthologs (AHR1A and AHR1B), independent of CYP1A induction. This is highly unlikely, as cyp1a is consistently the most highly induced gene following AHR activation (Alexeyenko et al., 2010; Carney et al., 2006). There is no simple mechanism to explain how BkF could induce CYP1A in an AHR2-dependent manner in epidermal cells, but fail to induce CYP1A in myocardial cells. An alternative explanation is that cardiac toxicity in BkF-exposed embryos is a result of a metabolite of BkF, or another metabolic alter- ation resulting from BkF exposure. BkF toxicity was moderately increased by CYP1A knockdown, which could indicate either that the parent compound causes toxicity, or that more parent compound is accessible to another metabolic pathway. The interaction between BkF and the standard control morpholino is unusual and also could impli- cate a metabolic mechanism. The standard control morpholino targets a splice site in the human ß-globin gene, has no antisense activity in zebrafish cells, and was selected for its absence of off-target biological activity or toxicity (Lacerra et al., 2000) (http://www.gene-tools.com/ node/23#standardcontrols). Some morpholinos have been shown to produce off-target toxicity causing apoptotic cell death through the p53 pathway (Robu et al., 2007). We have used the standard control morpholino with several other PAHs, and have not observed a similarly increased sensitivity to PAH toxicity (Incardona et al., 2006). There are no similar published findings that may suggest a plausible hypothesis underlying this effect. A BLAST search against the current zebrafish genome database with this sequence reveals only two anonymous sequences that have a partial (19 base pair) overlapwith themorpholino target sequence. Therefore, the control morpholino cannot be targeting a known member of the AHR or cytochrome P450 family. The observed synergism cannot be due to a generalmetabolic property ofmorpholinos, because the effectwas sequence-specific, i.e. did not occurwith either the ahr2-specific negative control morpholino, or the ahr2 antisense morpholino. The PAH compositions derived from non-point sources such as stormwater runoff are complex and typically reflect a mixture of com- bustive and petrogenic sources (Hwang and Foster, 2006; Stein et al., 2006). Comparison of dissolved-phase and particulate-associated PAHs usually shows a predominance of 2- and 3-ring compounds in the dis- solved phase, with a predominance of 4-, 5-, and 6-ring compounds in the particulate fraction. While the bulk of larger particle-associated PAHs may not be bioavailable to organisms such as fish embryos that are primarily impacted bydissolved PAHs (Carls et al., 2008), a key ques- tion is how lower concentrations of compounds such as BaP and BkF might modify the toxicity of a mixture that is otherwise predominantly petrogenic. Because CYP1A induction is primarily protective against pet- rogenic PAH toxicity (Hicken et al., 2011; Incardona et al., 2005), the presence of low concentrations of potent CYP1A inducers could poten- tially reduce the effects of 3-ring compounds in amixture. Alternatively, if CYP1A metabolic capacity was already overwhelmed by higher con- centrations of low molecular weight PAHs (which occurs at about 10 μg/L in zebrafish; (Hicken et al., 2011), the high molecular weight compounds may produce additive or greater-than-additive (i.e., syner- gistic) impacts on cardiac function and morphogenesis. The finding that the various mixtures of BeP, BaP, and BkF did not produce interme- diate levels of toxicity suggests that there may be more complicated in- teractions between these compounds, which should be examined in more detailed studies. In conclusion, these findings refine and extend our understanding of how individual PAHs cause developmental toxicity via a diversity of tox- icokinetic and toxicodynamic processes. This understanding is critical for assessing the combinatorial toxicity of PAHmixtures in aquatic hab- itats, both within and between petrogenic and pyrogenic sources. There are numerous implications for improving environmental assessment in PAH-contaminated environments. This includes, for example, future as- sessments of oil spill impacts (primarily petrogenic PAH mixtures) in riverine, estuarine, or coastal marine habitats where inputs from urban stormwater runoff (primarily pyrogenic mixtures) are common. A long-term goal of this work is to develop mechanism-based markers of the biological effects of complex PAHmixtures in sensitive early life his- tory stages of fish. This goal is dependent on a detailed understanding of the various pathways through which PAH toxicity converges on the de- veloping fish heart. Although the results of our zebrafish screening approach with high concentrations of single compounds may not be environmentally relevant, they shed light on pathways (e.g. AHR- dependent and novel AHR-independent) for which gene expression markers can be developed and tested with real-world mixtures. These types of mechanistic analyses using the zebrafish model will ultimately inform the development of a new generation of biomarkers that will be diagnostic of different types of PAH exposures in fish spawning habitats and, at the same time, phenotypically anchored to cardiac performance, heart and vascular development, and fish survival. Cardiac toxicity of 5-ring polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons is differentially dependent on the aryl hydrocarbon receptor 2 isoform during zebrafish development Introduction Materials and methods Outline placeholder Chemicals Zebrafish exposures Morpholino injections Imaging of live embryos/larvae and measurements of cardiac function Immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy Statistical analysis Results Benzo[a]pyrene and benzo[k]fluoranthene exposure results in distinct cardiac defects Benzo[a]pyrene, benzo[e]pyrene, and benzo[k]fluoranthene induce CYP1A in distinct tissue-specific patterns Cardiac toxicity of benzo[a]pyrene but not benzo[k]fluoranthene is AHR2-dependent Discussion Conflict of interest statement Acknowledgments References

content.CoiStatement: In summary, the present results provide an advance in our under- standing of the mechanisms associated with the development of ethanol-induced hypertension. Our results show a progressive increase in arterial pressure that is already evident at the onset of ethanol con- sumption. Increased vascular responsiveness to vasoconstrictor agents may contribute to the increase in blood pressure, possibly establishing a link factor in thehypertension development induced by ethanol inges- tion. Baroreflex changes were secondary to hypertension, but may con- tribute to maintain the hypertensive state and the increased risk of cardiac events in later stages of ethanol ingestion. The present study provides the first evidence of alterations in angiotensinergic mecha- nisms and CNP content within the NTS of ethanol-treated rats, which may be related to autonomic changes, as well as to neuroendocrine ef- fects evoked by ethanol. Finally, facilitated vascular responsiveness to NO seems to be an important mechanism counteracting ethanol- induced hypertension during later phases of ethanol ingestion. In conclusion, the present investigation extends earlier reports regarding the protective actions of carvedilol against the DOX-induced cardiotoxicity by demonstrating that this protective effect is due mainly to its antioxidant, and not h- adrenergic properties. Consequently, efforts to engineer new cardioprotective agents should focus on maximizing the antioxidant and not necessarily the autonomic properties of the drug. The results offer important substantiation for using this pharmacologically active agent as an adjunct to minimize the mitochondrial cardiomyopathy that limits the therapeutic success of DOX antineoplastic therapy. content.CoiStatement: Given that PCB74, PCB118, and PCB153 are congeners frequently found in environmental (Lake et al., 1995), wildlife (Kunisue et al., 2003), and human lipid and serum samples (Freels et al., 2007; Park et al., 2007; Larsen et al., 1994; Lanting et al., 1998), results from this study are relevant for ecological exposures. As the human body burden of the three PCB congeners used in this study varies considerably by individual and tissue, and it is difficult to extrapolate from in vitro to in vivo, the doses in our study were chosen to approximate human levels. (Freels et al., 2007; Park et al., 2007; Larsen et al., 1994; Lanting et al., 1998). Because PCBs differentially accumulate into microenvironments in living tissues, with levels reaching approximately 50 ppb in neonatal human brains (Lanting et al., 1998), developing neurons may be exposed to micromolar concentrations of these toxicants. This study establishes the role of PCBs in the induction of apoptosis in GnRH GT1-7 cells as a model for developing hypothalamic neurons. Future experiments in animal models will apply the present observations in GT1-7 cells on the effects of PCB exposure to the developing GnRH neurosecretory system. content.Funding: Cyclophosphamide also forms adducts with DNA (Mirkes et al., 1984), as do some PAHs in extractable TSP (Umbuzeiro et al., 2008b), which suggests that one possible mechanism of action of C. sylvestris ethanolic extract is the reduction of DNA adduct forma- tion. One of the consequences of DNA adduct formation is the clastogenic effect. When a sample such as C. sylvestris ethanolic ex- tract is able to decrease the number of micronuclei, it acts against ir- reparable DNA damage, which is manifested as chromosome aberrations or aneugenic effects, including clastogenicity (Scolastici et al., 2008). However, the comet assay detects primary DNA lesions that are reparable (Scolastici et al., 2008). In the present study, C. sylvestris ethanolic extract and casearin X both reduced the extent of such damage. Given that casearin X, a clerodane diterpene, did not reduce the percentage of micronuclei, another class of com- pounds must be responsible for this effect of C. sylvestris ethanolic ex- tract. The essential oil of C. sylvestris has also been shown to protect DNA from clastogenic damage, having been found to contain mono- terpenes and sesquiterpenes (Sousa et al., 2007). Oliveira et al. (2009) identified sesquiterpenes and clerodane diterpenes in the ethanolic extract of C. sylvestris. Of the 15 sesquiterpenes identified in the ethanolic extract, 13 had previously been identified in the essential oil (Esteves et al., 2005; Sousa et al., 2007). The protective effect of C. sylvestris ethanolic extract against irreparable DNA damage might be related also to its sesquiterpene content. In the present study, we observed that C. sylvestris ethanolic extract and casearin X have chemopreventive activity against DNA damage induced by TSP emitted from sugarcane burning. Our results suggest that C. sylvestris extract and diterpenes can act by different mechanisms to protect DNA against damage, including repairable and non-repairable damages. content.CoiStatement: From all of the results presented in the current study, it can be concluded that the exposure of pre-differentiated N2a cells to non-cytotoxic concentrations of CPF and CPO results in rapid neurite retraction and major disruption of the neurofilament net- work. These effects are not dependent on the inhibition of AChE but are associated with an early transient increase in the phosphor- ylation of NFH by ERK 1/2, followed by protein phosphatase- mediated hypophosphorylation. content.CoiStatement: 444 Y.-M. Kang et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 274 (2014) 436–444 (iii) PVN microinjection of ANG II induced an imbalance between pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines in the PVN, which was restored by pretreatment with losartan. Our findings provide further evidence and insight for the involvement of the RAS in the PVN and its interaction with neurotransmitters and cytokines in hypertension, which will provide a new target for the treatment of hypertension. Further explo- ration of these factor interactions within the brain may be beneficial towards the development of novel hypertensive therapeutics. content.CoiStatement: 105I. Riezzo et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 280 (2014) 97–106 Our previous study showed that high AASs doses administered over a long period is responsible for selective nephrotoxicity. This was dem- onstrated using the most common immunohistochemical and proteo- mic methods (D'Errico et al., 2011). Damaged, misfolded proteins bind to chaperones, and liberate the heat shock factor (HSF) from its chaper- one complexes. HSF is activated and the transcription of chaperone genes takes place (Morimoto, 2002; Soti and Csermely, 2003). Suscepti- bility to various types of proteotoxic damage is mainly increased due to the dysfunction ofmitochondrial oxidation. Collectively, these data sug- gest that TNF-α mediated injury due to nandrolone decanoate in renal cells appears to play a role in the activation of both the intrinsic and ex- trinsic pathways of apoptosis during long periods of injury. It is unlikely that TNF-α has a single effect to induce glomerulus cell apoptosis. The evidence gathered in this study clearly shows that multiple pathways could be activated in TNF-α-induced apoptosis in the glomerulus. It is likely that after long durations of injury, there is an oxidant-mediated activation of mitochondrial-derived apoptosis, with a switch to TNF-α receptor-mediated apoptosis following longer periods of injury (Maenpaa et al., 2008). Our experimental studies have confirmed the overexpression on mesangial cells of HSP90, IL-1β and TNF-α with in- tense reaction, in trained mice treated with high doses of nandrolone decanoate. In conclusion, the nephrotoxicity induced in nandrolone- treatedmice is closely associatedwith considerable dose-related oxida- tive stress. content.CoiStatement: There are many gaps in our understanding of the relative safety of arsenic to the human population. Importantly, most studies to date have focused on the effect of arsenic alone and not taken into consid- eration risk-modifying factors. Furthermore, even fewer studies have tested the possibility that arsenic may be a risk modifying factor for other diseases. It was shown here that arsenic enhances experimental NAFLD in mice. Although the increase in liver injury caused by arsenic under these conditions, NAFLD is a chronic disease that requires sev- eral years to progress (Adams et al., 2005), so relatively small changes can be greatly amplified over time. These results therefore suggest that the relative risk of hepatic damage caused by arsenic exposure may have to be modified to take into account other mitigating factors, such as underlying fatty liver disease. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our results suggest the mechanisms responsible for anti-allergic inflammatory activity of chrysin. We suggest that chrysin reduces histamine release via regulating intracellular calcium and inhibits inflammatory cytokines through suppressing caspase-1 and NF-κB. We provide evidence that chrysin could contribute to the prevention or treatment of mast cell-mediated allergic inflammatory disorders.
